The Apartheid Regime who had risen to power in 1948 favoured racial segregation over anything and would establish laws to follow through with that vision. In 1955 it decided to destroy Sophiatown and remove its inhabitants to SOWETO and other townships according to their race.
They came at the break of dawn on the 9th of February 1955 and levelled Sophiatown to the ground. To mock Sophiatown´s people even more they named the left over area Triomf (Afrikaans for, well, triumph) and settled white people. Sophiatown was gone by any means. Though its artists mostly followed their careers in exile, and it was renamed Sophiatown in 2006, its cultural heritage never fully recovered from that stroke and some of it is considered to be lost and forgotten.
 
The Budget
In order to see our vision come to life we have calculated a budget in the total sum of ZAR 213.000 or € 14.760 . The Budget consists of the following:

The biggest part of the budget will go to the technical support. With the kind support of the renowned companies Gearhouse South Africa and Mushroom Productions we could already reduce the costs for Technical Support and Production Support by 60% from their normal quotations. The musical artists we want to work with also kindly agreed to reduced fees.
The costs for venue hiring will go to the Trevor Huddleston Memorial Center in Sophiatown, where the event will take place. Costs for the Photo exhibition consist of copyright fees.
This Chart might give you an even better understanding of how the budget will be spent:

 
 
The Perks
We do not just want your money, we want you to get something back. Support us by spending your money on one or more of our perks:
Buy a ticket to our event for an early bird offer and printed in form of a dome pass printed by famous print artists Alphabet Zoo
https://www.instagram.com/alphabet_zoo/ http://alphabetzoosa.tumblr.com/ 
Buy a meet and greet ticket and get to talk to the Artists such as Mc Coy Mrubata, Sibusiso Lerole and more who will participate in the event.
 
Get the latest album of McCoy Mrubata with a personal signature.

 
Get your own Sophiatown Art Prints. Choose between two designs or take both. Designed by visual artist Sakhile Gumbi in reference to photographs of Jürgen Schadeberg and printed by famous print artists Alphabet Zoo
https://www.instagram.com/alphabet_zoo/ http://alphabetzoosa.tumblr.com/ 
The print "Pennywhistlers":

 
The print "Inside Shebeen":

 
Get your Sophiatown bag. Designed by artist Sakhile Gumbi in reference to photographs of Jürgen Schadeberg and printed by famous print artists Alphabet Zoo
https://www.instagram.com/alphabet_zoo/ http://alphabetzoosa.tumblr.com/

 
The Team
Who is pursuing this vision? Three individuals from two different continents who share one vision.

Mtsembeni Masina (left) from South Africa, 31 years old, based in Johannesburg, worked in the arts and entertainment industry as a lighting auto technician and sound engineer for 10 years. He produces films for the past 4 years.
"I have been always highly involved within the arts. My music and literature appreciation was shaped by the golden era and generation of Sophiatown."
Dr. Kristina Kreul (center) from Germany, 34 years old, based in Berlin, worked as a lawyer and branch manager in the healthcare sector for five years. Dances Flamenco for the past nine years and Lindy Hop and Solo Jazz for one year.
"As a Lindy Hop dancer I saw Sophiatown´s history with the mindset that the Lindy Hop culture, which originated in the late 1920´s, once was lost but was brought back by some few Swedes in the 1980´s. Now it is a worldwide hopping community of roughly 60.000 dancers. I am wishing for a worldwide recognition of Sophiatown and its incredible rich cultural heritage. "
Sakhile Gumbi (right) from Swaziland, 29 years old, based in Mbabane, works as graphic designer, university lecturer and photographer. Generally gifted with creative expression, he will release his first music album soon.
"As a photographer I always was and keep on being influenced a lot by the work of Jurgen Schadeberg and Bob Gosani, photographers that captured the essence of life in Sophiatown through the camera lense."
 
The Credits
We want to thank our most important supporters so far. Without you all this would not have been and will not be possible! Siyabonga khakhulu and thank you so much!
Alphabet Zoo, Ariane Labat, Brendan and Muriel Argent, Chantal Nyandwi, Eugene Maliboho, Fruitcake Vintage, Gearhouse South Africa, Lena Soennichsen, Marie Bergdahl, Mbali Zwane, Mc Coy Mrubata, Molato Mokoena, Mojgan Derakshani, Mushroom Production, Mxolisi Mathebula, Radiant Child, Peppy Sibayoni, Sibusiso Lerole Jun., Sizwe Nhlkeo, Skhumbuzo Hadebe, Steph O´Connor, Sthembiso Mngadi, Stanley Hlwatshwayo, Thembinkosi Mavimbela, Vuyiswa Ntombela and the communities of Alexandra Township and Newtown.

story:
About Promote Lebanon

Promote Lebanon is your ultimate companion to discover the hidden destinations and the ravishing stories behind them. From the Ottomans, the French and way back to the Phoenicians have all written their stories here. We will take you on a unique experience that will satisfy your curiosity and widen your knowledge. Lebanon has compelling hidden treasures to find. What makes Lebanon striking are those stories to tell behind every castle and every tree. Everybody has a different way of telling a story Promote Lebanon has its own unique way of storytelling by arousing your curiosity and imagination.

 

  • This project is created by Dr Krystle Houiess and Dr Sharif Abdunnur from the Department of Mass Media and Communication at the University of Balamand in Lebanon.  
  • The project will be fully run by students hungry to better their national image and international image with the guidance of the best professionals in the field of film making and documentary work.
  • The results will be astonishing: a unique library of free extremely interesting and exciting short films and documentaries about a all subjects relating to Lebanon from sports, tourism, food, culture, history and entertainment.
  • A first of its kind project with over 100 films released per year on International TV and all over social media.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The University of Balamand is fully backing the project and will provide 50% of the cost as well as the training, professors, and support.    But due to the size of the project we still your support:

  • We need to raise $350,000 USD to fund the project for two years
  • Amazing gifts and perks from personalized items to entire studios named after you: immortalizing your contributions and support for ever. 
  • All funds will go directly to pay for expenses of filming and operational costs as well as support for students to complete the films. 

 

The Impact

  • More than ever we need positive publicity for Lebanon and exposure.
  • We need positive international publicity for the Entire Arab World and this project is a great way to achieve this.
  • These videos will circulate and on International TV, Local stations and Web Social Networks providing an amazing amount of exposure and continuity.
  • With more than 50 International Awards for the films and documentary work the directors of the project are ready and passionate about not only producing these films but creating award winning short films to tell ravishing tales of this glorious country and all it has to offer. 

 

Even the Smallest Contribution Helps Us Meet Our Goals

 

And even if you cannot contribute then help us spread the word about this amazing project…. Post share… email…

story:
Britain's poorest town has decided to offer free breakfasts to all its primary school pupils in an extravagant first for the country.Why is that?

Blackpool is one of the most famous seaside tourist towns in Britain.Beaches, bars and roller coasters make you linger.

Behind all the hype is a jarring fact: Blackpool is the sixth-poorest district in Britain.A quarter of adults are on the dole, and the rate of living off benefits is double the national average.

 

The "luxury" of a poor town

Earlier this year, Blackpool local council teamed up with the University of North Sambria in a three-month experiment to provide free breakfasts to pupils at 33 primary schools across the region.Breakfast consists of milk, juice, bread, cereal, yogurt and fresh fruit.

After three months of eating, I came to the following conclusions:

Kids who get free breakfasts eat healthier

Free breakfasts can reduce inequalities in the nutritional quality of children's diets

Students are happier, more active and more focused

Attendance and class performance improved significantly

Parents and teachers are demanding that it be continued

Blackpool council has announced it will introduce free breakfasts from next year based on the results of the trial, with £1.3m earmarks to provide free nutritious breakfasts to all 12,000 primary school pupils in the borough.

 

12, An hour in the day is worth breakfast

There's a little background here.Public primary and secondary schools in Britain are required to provide lunches for their pupils.Children from poor families can apply for free meals, while other students pay a certain percentage of the cost of food.Schools are not obliged to provide breakfast.Some schools organize "breakfast clubs" where students pay extra for breakfast.

Blackpool council's decision, the first of its kind in the country, to offer free breakfasts to all schoolchildren is currently the only one.

Blackpool local authority leader John Blackburn says primary school teachers across the district report that many students are coming to school hungry and unable to concentrate.And as benefits have been cut, the number of students going to school hungry has increased significantly.

In fact, says Blackburn, the experiment proved its worth from day one: "I'm proud that we took such a bold decision and that no other local authority has tried anything like it.I'm even prouder of the results of our experiment.

Hodkins, the head teacher, said children who had eaten little or no breakfast before were now able to eat a big breakfast before the start of the day and were significantly more active and alert.It is too early to say whether it will help improve academic performance, but there has been a marked improvement in students' class attention and attendance.

 

To feed

Blackpool's initiative is the first of its kind in the country, but the reason for offering free breakfasts to children is not unique.

The Blackpool experiment comes as the Royal College of GPs, the National Association of Head Teachers and the Royal Society of Paediatrics and Child Health have joined a petition calling on the government to provide free breakfasts to pupils who qualify for free school meals.

Their separate surveys found that four out of five teachers reported having students in their class come to school on an empty stomach.A third of teachers said they regularly brought their own food such as biscuits and bread to keep pupils hungry.One in six primary school teachers spend an average of ￡25 a month on their own food for their children.

There are two main reasons why children do not eat breakfast. One is that parents do not pay attention to or have no energy to prepare breakfast, and the other is that they have no money to provide breakfast for their children.

The Royal College of GPs said ensuring children had a good breakfast could tackle a range of childhood illnesses caused by poor diet.

Eradell, president of the National Association of Head Teachers, said it was sad for children to go to school hungry.How do you study on an empty stomach?The National Association of Head Teachers is calling on the government to try offering free breakfasts to all pupils who need or are entitled to free school meals.

 

The pauper

Perhaps, like Blackpool, the rich-world hat does not cover the gap between rich and poor in British society.

Official government figures show that one in five children in the UK live below the poverty line, one of the highest rates in any developed western country.(Britain's official poverty line is defined as a family earning less than 60% of the national average.)

In some traditional industrial cities, and even some parts of inner London, almost half of all children live below the poverty line.

The government insists its target of eradicating child poverty by 2020 remains unchanged.But efforts to lift children out of poverty have been severely hampered by deep cuts in public spending since the financial crisis.

The Institute for Fiscal Studies predicts that the number of children living in poverty in the UK will instead rise by 800,000 by 2020.

Deep cuts in public spending in Britain have forced local authorities to close and roll over many welfare and convenience programmes.In a penny to break into two spend time, spend money where, focus on what to protect?

One poor English town has its answer.Let's hope the free school breakfasts in Blackpool continue.

Our free breakfasts will also keep more children from hunger and cold！！

story:
Saving St. Ignatius Hospital

A turn-of-the-century hospital, tucked away and abandoned in a rural town. Would you save it if you could?

Saint Ignatius Hospital was designed and built by fearless nun and architect, Mother Joseph. Completed in 1893, the hospital continued for decades until it was eventually decommissioned in 1968. The building continued to be used as a home for elderly and mentally disabled adults, until 2003, when it was finally abandoned.

Nearly 20 years of neglect have brought St. Ignatius dangerously close to ruin. The hospital has been on Washington state's "Most Endangered" historic buildings list since 2015. A massive hole in the west side of the roof has caused four floors to notably sag. It's difficult to tell how close we are to the “point of no return”— major structural failure which would put the building beyond reasonable repair. We need to raise the sagging floors and replace the roof soon in order to preserve the building.

St. Ignatius needs your help

And so do we! We're Austin and Laura Storm, and small business and historic preservation is our catnip. We currently run two independent secondhand stores—one in Moscow, Idaho, and one in Colfax, Washington. Plus we’ve got plans for a bookstore, a downtown hotel, a bar...the list goes on! But St. Ignatius Hospital trumps all those. It’s the white whale, the pearl of great price, the cherry on top, the thing that makes us mix our metaphors.

Now, we’re embarking on a quest larger than any we’ve yet attempted—to preserve and restore the St. Ignatius Hospital. This is an immense project, and it will literally take a village. The Whitman County Historical Society has approved the preservation of St. Ignatius as a sponsored project; we have a partnership with the Colfax Chamber who runs haunted and historic hospital tours; and thanks to all of you, an army of heartfelt volunteers and enthusiastic old-building fanatics! Together we can save St. Ignatius!

Long-term vision

St. Ignatius began as a place for others, and we want to restore it to that again. We would love to see it shine as a historic event venue and hotel, with space for artist retreats, maker classes, food & drink, small businesses, and more. It'll be a long, wonderful haul to bring it back!

Current goals

Right now, we have two key challenges:

  1. Retire the mortgage. We have a short-term mortgage of $50,000 which is coming due soon. Once this is paid off, it will free up funds every month to continue to do vital repairs.
  2. Roof and structural rescue. This incredible building needs time to dry out with a proper roof, but every spring, fall, and winter, it just gets hit with more rain, sleet, and snow. It's wearing the structure down, and it's unlikely that the hospital can withstand many more wet seasons without significant repairs.

We realize those are both big goals, so we’re very thankful to share that an anonymous donor has pledged a generous “matching gift” of up to $50,000 for the preservation of St. Ignatius. This means that every dollar you donate during this campaign will be doubled, up to $50,000!

Come join the St. Ignatius effort

  1. DONATE to our roof and structural rescue. We would love to start structural repairs on St. Iggy's before this next winter hits!
  2. FOLLOW @stignatiuscolfax on Instagram. Click the Notification button to know when we post or share stories.
  3. SHARE the campaign with your family and friends—everybody loves a good fixer-upper!
  4. JOIN our email list for even more details and updates.
  5. FOLLOW YOUR OWN CRAZY DREAMS. Every shop opened, old building saved, restaurant started, and trail developed, adds verve and beauty to our community, and encourages the rest of us to keep on!

story:
The Short, Short Version

A New England Martial Arts Studio is in danger of being lost, along with the 60-year history of their Grandmaster instructor, who passed away at the beginning of 2020. Two students have found a way to get the studio back, secure the history of their teacher, and pass on his lessons to future generations.

His Legacy, Our Future...

On January 29, 2020, the students of the Beaudoin Academy of Karate of Waterbury, CT USA lost their Master Instructor and Academy owner, Dr. Robert E. Beaudoin. He was a prominent figure in American Martial Arts with a career that spanned six decades and ended with him being the Grandmaster of the World Tang Soo Do Association.

With his passing began a series of legal trials and tribulations only made more difficult by a global pandemic, resulting in the near loss of his studio, where he taught thousands of students for more than 30 years. But now we have an opportunity to return the Academy to its students, and turn it into a proper Memorial site of this amazing human being. But we need your help to make it happen.


Who is Grandmaster Robert Beaudoin, what is the Academy of Karate, and Why Does it Matter?



While stationed in Korea with the U.S. Air Force during the Vietnam War, Robert Beaudoin started training in Tang Soo Do, a traditional Korean Martial Art and earned his black belt in 1963 under his teacher- Grandmaster Jae C. Shin. Not long after returning to the states, he opened the Academy of Karate in Connecticut and began training students in 1965. He would later become a charter member of the World Tang Soo Do Association in 1982. Today, the WTSDA has over 100,000 members across 36 countries. He then became Grandmaster of the Association in 2010. But the Academy was always his school and the students that trained there learned from him directly. No matter what corners of the world Association business brought him to, he always made sure to come home and teach his students. 


Martial Artists would come from all over the world to train at the Academy of Karate to learn from this remarkable and warm man.  He would receive gifts and lessons from the different cultures and his Academy became a Mini-Museum of his travels.

The Academy of Karate is a symbol of Traditional Martial Arts in New England and for his students, some who have also become instructors and Masters over the years, it's a home and a family. 

The Passing of an Icon

Grandmaster Beaudoin's passing was sudden and unexpected. It presented a host of legal issues over who owned the multiple decades-old property and who would take over as Master Instructor, if one of the students could even regain control of the property. Multiple businesses wanted the location and didn't much care about the lineage of an aging Martial Arts school.

Then two months later, the global pandemic hit. Further turmoil met the Academy as it had to close down completely until all of the red tape could be worked through. Insurance issues meant that taking care of the property wasn't allowed as ownership was in purgatory. Repairs needed to be made. If something wasn't done soon, 55 years of history would be lost.
 

Someone steps up to the Plate

Enter Anthony Bracco and Dan Farrelly. Anthony is a long time local small business owner and student of the Academy for over 20 years. Dan is a Computer Science Engineer and trained under Grandmaster Beaudoin for over 30 years. Anthony's daughters are black belts, Dan met his wife (A 4th-degree Black Belt Master Instructor and 3-time Regional Champion herself) there. The Beaudoin Academy of Karate was a part of their lives that they weren't so willing to let go. 

Anthony had the experience at running a business and Dan had the experience at running the Academy, taking the lead any time Grandmaster Beaudoin was away. Together, they came up with a plan to save the spirit of the Academy of Karate while also updating it and rebuilding it for future generations. But it's going to take a village.

 

The Plan

Anthony managed to cut through the red tape and has secured an agreement with the Beaudoin family to buy the Academy, as is. That alone was a costly endeavor. Upon doing all the inspections necessary, and the reality of a post-pandemic world, it was seen that major upgrades needed to be made.  The heating / ventilation system, roof repair, parking lot irrigation, along with expanding the facility's training floor, office space, and storage. Even adding an outdoor training space for the warmer months and for safer training.

Aside from the renovation, work will be put into properly preserving and displaying the many pieces of history that highlight the fascinating journey of Dr. Robert E. Beaudoin, the man behind the Academy and creating a mini-museum of sorts.

The $75,000 we've set as an initial target is only about half of what it will take to do all of these things, with Anthony taking on the pressure of the other half. But this wasn't meant to make money. Every dollar raised for this project will go directly into the Academy. 

This is a symbol of the legacy of the Beaudoin Academy of Karate. A wall of Black Belts dating back to the late 60s. Grandmaster Beaudoin trained all regardless of race, gender, or beliefs, even at a time when that wasn't looked to kindly upon. He believed everyone deserves a place to train. A family. That is the legacy he created and the future we hope to continue with this project.

The Challenges of this Project

We're reopening a martial arts studio during a Global pandemic. That challenge is pretty obvious. More so, renovations take time and we want to make sure we do everything correctly. So we're hitting ground running. Our goal is to be open by April 2021, under the guidance of whatever the State guidelines are to keep our students safe. Even if we have to start classes virtually, we will have our home ready to welcome everyone back when the time is right. We plan on keeping everyone in the loop every step of the way with regular video and photo updates. We're not only saving a family, but we're building a community. 

 

Our Gifts for Donors

Bumper Sticker

11 x 17 Poster

T-Shirt

Pullover Hoodie
story_txt:
The Short, Short Version
A New England Martial Arts Studio is in danger of being lost, along with the 60-year history of their Grandmaster instructor, who passed away at the beginning of 2020. Two students have found a way to get the studio back, secure the history of their teacher, and pass on his lessons to future generations.
His Legacy, Our Future...
On January 29, 2020, the students of the Beaudoin Academy of Karate of Waterbury, CT USA lost their Master Instructor and Academy owner, Dr. Robert E. Beaudoin. He was a prominent figure in American Martial Arts with a career that spanned six decades and ended with him being the Grandmaster of the World Tang Soo Do Association.With his passing began a series of legal trials and tribulations only made more difficult by a global pandemic, resulting in the near loss of his studio, where he taught thousands of students for more than 30 years. But now we have an opportunity to return the Academy to its students, and turn it into a proper Memorial site of this amazing human being. But we need your help to make it happen.

Who is Grandmaster Robert Beaudoin, what is the Academy of Karate, and Why Does it Matter?
While stationed in Korea with the U.S. Air Force during the Vietnam War, Robert Beaudoin started training in Tang Soo Do, a traditional Korean Martial Art and earned his black belt in 1963 under his teacher- Grandmaster Jae C. Shin. Not long after returning to the states, he opened the Academy of Karate in Connecticut and began training students in 1965. He would later become a charter member of the World Tang Soo Do Association in 1982. Today, the WTSDA has over 100,000 members across 36 countries. He then became Grandmaster of the Association in 2010. But the Academy was always his school and the students that trained there learned from him directly. No matter what corners of the world Association business brought him to, he always made sure to come home and teach his students. Martial Artists would come from all over the world to train at the Academy of Karate to learn from this remarkable and warm man.  He would receive gifts and lessons from the different cultures and his Academy became a Mini-Museum of his travels.The Academy of Karate is a symbol of Traditional Martial Arts in New England and for his students, some who have also become instructors and Masters over the years, it's a home and a family. 

The Passing of an Icon

Grandmaster Beaudoin's passing was sudden and unexpected. It presented a host of legal issues over who owned the multiple decades-old property and who would take over as Master Instructor, if one of the students could even regain control of the property. Multiple businesses wanted the location and didn't much care about the lineage of an aging Martial Arts school.Then two months later, the global pandemic hit. Further turmoil met the Academy as it had to close down completely until all of the red tape could be worked through. Insurance issues meant that taking care of the property wasn't allowed as ownership was in purgatory. Repairs needed to be made. If something wasn't done soon, 55 years of history would be lost. 

Someone steps up to the Plate


Enter Anthony Bracco and Dan Farrelly. Anthony is a long time local small business owner and student of the Academy for over 20 years. Dan is a Computer Science Engineer and trained under Grandmaster Beaudoin for over 30 years. Anthony's daughters are black belts, Dan met his wife (A 4th-degree Black Belt Master Instructor and 3-time Regional Champion herself) there. The Beaudoin Academy of Karate was a part of their lives that they weren't so willing to let go. Anthony had the experience at running a business and Dan had the experience at running the Academy, taking the lead any time Grandmaster Beaudoin was away. Together, they came up with a plan to save the spirit of the Academy of Karate while also updating it and rebuilding it for future generations. But it's going to take a village.
 
The Plan
Anthony managed to cut through the red tape and has secured an agreement with the Beaudoin family to buy the Academy, as is. That alone was a costly endeavor. Upon doing all the inspections necessary, and the reality of a post-pandemic world, it was seen that major upgrades needed to be made.  The heating / ventilation system, roof repair, parking lot irrigation, along with expanding the facility's training floor, office space, and storage. Even adding an outdoor training space for the warmer months and for safer training.Aside from the renovation, work will be put into properly preserving and displaying the many pieces of history that highlight the fascinating journey of Dr. Robert E. Beaudoin, the man behind the Academy and creating a mini-museum of sorts.The $75,000 we've set as an initial target is only about half of what it will take to do all of these things, with Anthony taking on the pressure of the other half. But this wasn't meant to make money. Every dollar raised for this project will go directly into the Academy. 
This is a symbol of the legacy of the Beaudoin Academy of Karate. A wall of Black Belts dating back to the late 60s. Grandmaster Beaudoin trained all regardless of race, gender, or beliefs, even at a time when that wasn't looked to kindly upon. He believed everyone deserves a place to train. A family. That is the legacy he created and the future we hope to continue with this project.
The Challenges of this Project
We're reopening a martial arts studio during a Global pandemic. That challenge is pretty obvious. More so, renovations take time and we want to make sure we do everything correctly. So we're hitting ground running. Our goal is to be open by April 2021, under the guidance of whatever the State guidelines are to keep our students safe. Even if we have to start classes virtually, we will have our home ready to welcome everyone back when the time is right. We plan on keeping everyone in the loop every step of the way with regular video and photo updates. We're not only saving a family, but we're building a community. 
 
Our Gifts for Donors
Bumper Sticker

11 x 17 Poster

T-Shirt

Pullover Hoodie

story:
Giving All Access

I'm author, editor, speaker, and entrepreneur John Edward Lawson. My background is as an award-winning publisher of cross-genre books nobody else will publish because they'll be difficult to market. A regular day for me involves making products other business people avoid, and proving those products can succeed.

Now I'm taking that experience, along with my work as an event planner, and launching virtual conventions, workshops, trade shows, and more…with your help.

This project isn't about developing a single stand-alone convention, it's about building an online platform to continually provide the experience of conventions and workshops for those who cannot attend such events in person.

For the first time, all members of the science fiction, fantasy, and horror communities and beyond — regardless of worldwide location, mobility, identity, or resources — will have regularly-occurring access to convention guests, vendors, keynote speeches, and networking opportunities with other fans and industry professionals through virtual events that function in the same way as in-person events.

All of which will be offered for a much lower price point than brick-and-mortar versions of these events, typically in the $27 to $47 range as opposed to the standard $80 to $300 plus travel, food, and accommodations.

Our community has members who are not just underserved, they are often mistreated or left out entirely. Your contribution will make our plan even more effective, make the scene as powerful as possible, and give you lifetime access.

How We Get There Together

Here's the best part: this is all within reach. The amounts of money we're talking about are not outrageous.

The bare minimum to purchase the technology needed for achieving our goal is $600. That's it! At $2,000 we cover a lot of the business-related expenses that would otherwise prevent us from delivering events to you right away. Above $2,000 in funding helps establish our infrastructure and publicity efforts for reaching and working with the communities we intend to engage.

Evergreen Attendees get free lifetime basic admission to our online events. Evergreen VIPs receive lifetime VIP admission to our online events. Evergreen Vendors unlock lifetime access to the vendor area of our online events to sell or market their product, company, or service in addition to being part of the event as an attendee. UPDATE: public-facing chat is now enabled in the vendor booths so you can interact with attendees and answer their questions! Evergreen Sponsors will have sponsorship status at our online events for life along with a virtual vendor booth in the expo area, in addition to having an Evergreen attendee membership. The benefits of those four contribution levels are active for any and all of our public events but may be subject to restrictions from business partners on the occasions when we cohost an event with another organization.

Evergreen Legacy contributors get all the benefits listed above, plus we'll create a grant in your name to allow free access for people who wouldn't otherwise be able to attend our events. We administrate the grant through an easy to find, easy to understand application process. Your name becomes that of a benefactor and philanthropist.

If we don't reach our entire goal any money received goes into a version of this that, while good, does not allow us to support the community to the extent we know is possible. So, regardless of the outcome, your contribution brings something good to life!

Your Influence

Your contribution, combined with our experience, will make an immediate and valuable impact:

  • That favorite author who lives in a remote area, that reviewer who expanded your horizons before a car crash limited their public life, that instructor who inspired your heroes before aging out of traveling the convention circuit…these people and more are waiting to hang out with you just on the other side of the donate button.
  • During our time publishing, we have successfully planned and coordinated workshops, conventions, book tours, retreats, and more with organizations, individuals, and businesses not just for ourselves and the authors we work with, but on behalf of other communities as well. With your help, we'll be able to eliminate all the associated waste and massive carbon footprint our events currently generate.
  • My personal work as vice president of Diverse Writers and Artists of Speculative Fiction, combined with my own experience, has demonstrated to me the necessity of removing barriers to entry for marginalized groups, people without extra resources, those who typically experience harassment, and people whose sobriety is put at risk in the "party" atmosphere of conventions hosted in hotels with bars. You deserve access to pursue your interests in the arts, career advancement, and more, with the biggest crowd possible so let's get rid of any obstacles together.

Risks & Challenges

Despite a track record of operating businesses 20+ years, starting with a recording studio in the mid-1990s, there are still always challenges. Some of those include:

  • The exact thing that makes this a great opportunity…nobody else is doing it! There are unknowns here, but looking at online summits in the information product space gives us clues as to how fandom and arts communities will respond.
  • The fact we have 20 years of experience in the business is a liability in addition to being a bonus because our other businesses are still operational and will require our attention. That's why we are using this platform to build the necessary infrastructure and team, in order to prevent budgetary confusion between businesses and to avoid overworked team members losing customer focus or giving up entirely.
  • One challenge to overcome is that our perks are only guaranteed for PUBLIC virtual events. Occasionally we will host private virtual events and cannot guarantee access…look, if somebody is having a private family reunion or virtual funeral service, do you really want to be there anyway? Equally important to note is that if we partner with another company to host an event that company may place restrictions on attendance. We'll work to ensure all our early adopter supporters have as much access as possible in those situations, though, since that's the point of All Access Conventions.
  • The other challenge is that while it's cool to reach unlimited thousands of attendees for life as a vendor or sponsor the above restrictions will apply for vendor/sponsor backers as well. We can't guarantee the ability to vend at or sponsor private events, or at events we cohost with other businesses. The good news is private events tend to have much smaller crowds, and cohosted events might be focused on really narrow niches outside your target audience, so you might not be missing much anyway.
  • Due to legal constraints for public events in the United States of America, we cannot accept sponsors or vendors who promote illegal activities or hate and/or violence.

Other Questions

If we're so great at business then why resort to crowdfunding?

As alluded to above we're intent on not letting down stakeholders in our established business efforts with unplanned expenditures. The opportunity to acquire the tech needed to launch this effort (massive online events that mirror real-world events, which has been a goal of ours for years) fell into our laps but time is limited for the price that is within reach for us. We're nearly there but just can't put the money together in the required timeframe.

So, instead of going after a loan or scrambling for investors we are taking it to the streets. This not only ensures the working capital necessary but also makes it possible to have users on board from the start, and a focus group who can help shape the way our online events develop. After all, the events are not for us, they're for the community of attendees, vendors, and sponsors.

You can find more in the FAQ section. If your questions aren't covered here please do reach out to us for answers! Thanks. And now, one final thing…

You Can Help Without Spending Money

Can't contribute? We've been there ourselves! But that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign! Tell people you might be interested either in person, via email, or sharing on social media.
  • Indiegogo has built-in sharing tools to make all of this easy. Or, if you prefer sharing in a way that feels more directly supportive, you can share posts from our social media accounts. Your support, in whatever form, is much appreciated!

We look forward to serving you, and the community at large. Thank you!

story:
We are excited to be officially reopening 14 Pews in October 2021! To get there, we need your help. Today, we’re kicking off our reopening campaign and need our community’s support to open our doors again after being closed for over 18 months. Please join us as we raise the funds to bring back engaging films and cultural events to our community. With your help, our community-based non-profit art house will begin our new fall season of fun events.

Please help us reach our crowdfunding goal of $50,000. You’ll receive special perks and gifts as a thank you, including 14 Pews memberships, limited-edition t-shirts, Theremin Fever Blu-Rays, and more. This is your opportunity to be a part of bringing back 14 Pews which is a central home of film in the Houston Heights. We know seeing cinema collectively connects us to one another. And we love to be connected to other film lovers. Together, with your help, we can bring back the Church of Cinema, so we can continue to celebrate with our friends, family and strangers this glorious artistic form in this beloved space.

story:
ADVANCE TICKET SALES ARE CLOSED - YOU CAN STILL DONATE TO THIS CAMPAIGN

Overview

Red Ex Vol. IV is the fourth annual one day music festival fundraiser hosted by The Red Museum in Downtown Sacramento. Our goal is to produce a great event for our community and to raise funds for our DIY artist warehouse space. If you can't make it to the event, there are other ways to help, too!


What: Red Ex Vol. IV

When: September 11, 2021 from 3 pm to 11 pm

Where: The Red Museum, 212 15th Street, Sacramento CA 95814

What: Two stages of music, art installations, beer, wine, creative cocktails, and local vegan food.

Lineup: La Luz // Drug Apts // DEFEM // Tre Burt // Camilla Covington // Joules Satyr (of Sea of Bees) // Kairos Creature Club // Eternity Hotline // Ex-Heir // Ego Death // Andrew Wayne

This event is ALL AGES.

Covid-19: We require proof of vaccination or negative COVID-19 test results (within 3 days of the event). Unvaccinated individuals must remain masked and socially distanced (6 feet apart). We reserve the right to update this public safety policy as recommended by the CDC, State of California, and the City of Sacramento.

What is The Red Museum?

The Red Museum is an old fruit-packing warehouse on the outskirts of Mansion Flats that has transformed into an epicenter of experimentation and raw arts culture in Sacramento. We provide affordable practice/studio space to local creatives and occasionally host highly-curated events that bring people of different ages, ethnicities, genders, economic backgrounds, and tastes together to experience new music, performance, food, and visual art for a reasonable entry price. We believe in the cultural value of providing exposure for emerging artists and we never want money to be a barrier between a good artist and a successful artist. We also want the public, no matter their demographic, to have access to this culture through our events.

This is the fourth year (skipping 2020) we have produced the Red Ex event, which raises funds that help us continue to operate throughout the year. Simply put, this event is how we survive. We’re looking to the community for support, but we are also giving back an event that represents the diversity of the current up-and-coming talent in our city. Sacramento has a warm community of artists and art supporters who are open to experiencing new things, making our city a unique incubator for creativity.

The success of this project will demonstrate that there is a path to helping art spaces survive in a changing and gentrifying city. By galvanizing support from they city, local businesses, and the community, we can ensure that the future of the arts is secure here in Sacramento. The Red Ex event tickets are the foundation of this campaign and we have added other special perks from there. We appreciate any support and hope we will see you soon at The Red Museum!

story:
Can you support a much-needed community arts event? Periscope are excited to announce that we are preparing a brand-new creative event to be held in Stroud town centre in October 2019, drawing together members of the public, commissioned artists, speakers, researchers, youth groups and community outreach groups in a wonderful communal creative project!

Hello! Periscope is a creative partnership between artists Alison Cockcroft and Emily Joy.

We are based in Stroud, Gloucestershire and both have many years experience of teaching in the area and nationwide. As educators and facilitators, we are passionate about breaking down barriers to participation with art and creativity and challenging hierarchies in teaching and learning.

We are also passionate about working within our own community, and committed to the importance of art and creativity being available to everyone. We believe strongly in the power of the arts to strengthen community, empower individuals and bring about social change. As Periscope we have developed a unique methodology, which cuts through barriers including age, experience, confidence and ability. 

Over the last 4 years we have provided 10 short duration Periscope events, reaching many hundreds of people in the area. From the 'Inventor's Workshop' to the 'Dream of the Plant Collector', Periscope have created unique spaces in which to explore and be creative.

 

We are excited to announce that we are now fund-raising for a month-long event to be held in Stroud town centre in October 2019!

'The Explorer's Dream' will reach a wider public and we hope will it become the start of a permanent creative presence in the town...

WHY? We believe that non-outcome based creative provision is now crucial; in relation to cuts to arts in schools, a reduction of adult involvement with the arts, and prohibitive costs of standard art workshops.  The value of participation in the arts to support wellbeing and improve mental health is now well documented. 

We are also excited by the possibility that open ended creativity can encourage the questioning of accepted social norms, creating alternative narratives that can empower individuals and connect people. Through a short scoping event we held in Stroud in October 2018, we could already see how by being in the town centre Periscope was reaching people who would otherwise not engage with the arts or with standard workshops.

We began to see what we hoped for: passers by popping in for a chat, a reminisce, some company... and being drawn gently into creative action; whether that was telling us a story, adding to a written piece, playing with some of our strange equipment and machinery to create a piece of work, or spending time drawing using some of our beautiful materials.

SO WHAT IS IT WE ARE PLANNING? 

'The Explorer's Dream' will explore how our imagination and memory create our ideas of place, wildness, the familiar and strange. A theatrical environment with props, tools and equipment will enable playful creative acts focusing on looking, making and drawing.

As with all Periscope events, this event will be free, drop-in, and structured to accommodate all ages and abilities.

AND THERE'S MORE! 

We are also fundraising for a one-day creative symposium which will explore Periscope’s methodology within the context of art, creativity and education. This symposium will explore ideas of creative education, social change, the reimagining of social narratives and the place of non-outcome based play, bringing together artists, researchers and theorists alongside the public of all ages. 

Contributors and speakers include

Dr Wendy Russell (Senior lecturer in play and play work, University of Gloucestershire) 

Sophie Christophy (consent based education)

Rowan Salim (Director, Free we Grow; democratic and alternative education),

Dougald Hine (Author, co-founder of Dark Mountain, Home - social change) 

and Jane Sillis (Director of Engage; public engagement with arts and galleries).

 

 

On the evening before this exciting symposium we will be welcoming hedgespoken (Tom and Rima Staines; travelling theatre and storytelling) and their beautiful van to the Goods Shed in Stroud for an evening of imaginative travels into the known and the unknown, drawing upon myths and ancient stories and looking at our relationship to the wild - tying in with our event space theme. See more at https://hedgespoken.org 

 

To make this event happen we need your generous and wonderful help!

We are fundraising to cover some of our costs for this event...

These sorts of events are not cheap: we work many months to research, prepare and get other creative people involved. We also provide beautiful quality materials and equipment plus a lot of props to create a truly unique environment. We value our contributors, whether they are speakers at events, our photographers, technical support or artists helping us create elements of the event. 

We also know that participants like to feel involved, and as all our events are free we know that many participants have wanted to help us continue providing these amazing and valuable experiences. 

 

We are looking to you to help us raise £500 to cover our materials and equipment costs for this event.

We will be buying inks, specialist clay, paper and fantastic props, and hiring projectors and buying other materials including wood and paint to create our interactive and immersive space.

If you can help us towards raising this initial £500 we will use it as part-funding for a larger funding bid which covers all other aspects of the event and symposium, including paying contributors and speakers, employing a local young filmmaker and a local evaluator. 

Even if we don't reach our entire goal, all the funds raised will go into the project as planned, funding as much as we can and delivering a fantastic experience! 

Are there rewards for supporting us? 

Yes! We love giving something back to our supporters!

Those able to support us will be given a thank you gift ranging from their name featured on the supporters page on our blog, to our symposium tickets.

And of course, however you can support us, you will be very much invited to come to the actual event in October!

 

Are there risks & challenges?

We are excited by this new project and are using it as an opportunity to fully evaluate our approach, which is why we are working with Alice Goodenough (evaluator) throughout the month long event.

We are hopeful that our presence will become established and known as a welcoming creative place for individuals, families, groups and vulnerable people in the community, and as a resource for creative making and social imagining.

With over 40 years teaching experience between us in many diverse environments and with many diverse groups of people, we feel strongly that something different is needed in arts provision. 

 

By the way, if you like what we do and if you would like to support us but can't make a financial pledge, there are other ways to help us realise this project:

  • You can talk to others about what we are doing
  • You can visit our blog www.periscopics.wordpress.com and contribute to our interactive elements, share our blog on social media and follow us on facebook!
  • Share this campaign on social media, by email or by word of mouth!

 

We really hope that you can support us in any way, large or small! 

Thank you, Ali and Emily at Periscope

Can you support a much-needed community arts event? Periscope are excited to announce that we are preparing a brand-new creative event to be held in Stroud town centre in October 2019, drawing together members of the public, commissioned artists, speakers, researchers, youth groups and community outreach groups in a wonderful communal creative project!
Hello! Periscope is a creative partnership between artists Alison Cockcroft and Emily Joy.

We are based in Stroud, Gloucestershire and both have many years experience of teaching in the area and nationwide. As educators and facilitators, we are passionate about breaking down barriers to participation with art and creativity and challenging hierarchies in teaching and learning.

We are also passionate about working within our own community, and committed to the importance of art and creativity being available to everyone. We believe strongly in the power of the arts to strengthen community, empower individuals and bring about social change. As Periscope we have developed a unique methodology, which cuts through barriers including age, experience, confidence and ability. 

Over the last 4 years we have provided 10 short duration Periscope events, reaching many hundreds of people in the area. From the 'Inventor's Workshop' to the 'Dream of the Plant Collector', Periscope have created unique spaces in which to explore and be creative.

 
We are excited to announce that we are now fund-raising for a month-long event to be held in Stroud town centre in October 2019!
'The Explorer's Dream' will reach a wider public and we hope will it become the start of a permanent creative presence in the town...
WHY? We believe that non-outcome based creative provision is now crucial; in relation to cuts to arts in schools, a reduction of adult involvement with the arts, and prohibitive costs of standard art workshops.  The value of participation in the arts to support wellbeing and improve mental health is now well documented. 
We are also excited by the possibility that open ended creativity can encourage the questioning of accepted social norms, creating alternative narratives that can empower individuals and connect people. Through a short scoping event we held in Stroud in October 2018, we could already see how by being in the town centre Periscope was reaching people who would otherwise not engage with the arts or with standard workshops.
We began to see what we hoped for: passers by popping in for a chat, a reminisce, some company... and being drawn gently into creative action; whether that was telling us a story, adding to a written piece, playing with some of our strange equipment and machinery to create a piece of work, or spending time drawing using some of our beautiful materials.

SO WHAT IS IT WE ARE PLANNING? 
'The Explorer's Dream' will explore how our imagination and memory create our ideas of place, wildness, the familiar and strange. A theatrical environment with props, tools and equipment will enable playful creative acts focusing on looking, making and drawing.
As with all Periscope events, this event will be free, drop-in, and structured to accommodate all ages and abilities.

AND THERE'S MORE! 
We are also fundraising for a one-day creative symposium which will explore Periscope’s methodology within the context of art, creativity and education. This symposium will explore ideas of creative education, social change, the reimagining of social narratives and the place of non-outcome based play, bringing together artists, researchers and theorists alongside the public of all ages.

Dr Wendy Russell (Senior lecturer in play and play work, University of Gloucestershire)

story:
Who are you supporting?

Vinotok is an autumn equinox festival celebrating nature, community and the harvest. The week of events includes a Harvest Mother Celebration at our local Farmer’s Market; a Mythology Workshop on the symbolism of our celebrations; women’s gatherings; a Storytelling evening with elders of our community; a Liar’s Night competition; an all organic, locally grown farm to table Community Feast; street theatre performances with a host of ancient and archetypal characters; and the Burning of the Grump Bonfire to release our grievances.

Support sacred activism that honors nature and community by donating to our truly grassroots, volunteer organized harvest festival. For 34-years we have celebrated the innate transitions in our world. We honor the arrival of fall and winter as well as the completion of a fleeting summer. 

Support an opportunity for a community to come together to revel with each other. Pay homage to the bond between generations within our community. Share the history of the people that treasure living here. Bring forth the storytelling traditions from our community’s ancestral ranching and mining heritages, and unite them with the stories we are creating in the present.  

Support a time of year where grievances against one another and ourselves are forgotten. Help us gather a community to celebrate the wildness, understand we are connected to the rhythms of nature. This will let us teach ourselves and our visitors to revere the bounty of a summer with harvest of wildflowers and food. 

Support us as we gather to be thankful for what we have been given. We will dance around a fire in abandon, to let go, and begin afresh our human role in the every-cycling circle of life.

What We Need & What You Get:

We are asking for the basic operational expenses required to run a week of festivities.

We need $16,200 for:

  • Grump Materials: For our local artist to build a one-of-the-kind work of art that is burned to represent our release of last year’s grumps ($1,000)
  • Bonfire Materials: So that we may provide a safe fire for our community including such items as fire ignition materials and fire extinguishers ($1,000)
  • Feast Food: To pay our local farmers what is costs to feed 350 people at an organic, volunteer led feast ($4,000)
  • Pochenka Materials: So that we may purchase the necessary supplies to for traditional Pachinko, a sustainably and humanely harvested roast pig to our Community Feast ($250)
  • Spirits: So our bellies may be warm while we wait for autumn with local and hand-crafted wine, mead, cider and ale ($1,000)
  • Feast Rentals: To provide tables and chairs to efficiently seat 350 people at our Community Feast, and chafing dishes to keep our food warm ($900)
  • Costumes: So we embody our natural surrounding and continue to provide our cast with the attire they need to set the tone ($500)
  • Decorations: To transform our town into a magical realm ($200)
  • Cast Provisions: Nourishing food for our performing and volunteering cast of 100 so they may not pass out from famish and feel honored for their vast contributions culminating in thousands of hours of volunteer time ($1,000)
  • Sound System: So, all can hear our declarations from the stage as we put the Grump on Trial ($350)
  • Recycling, Compost and Trash: So our Green Team reaches our goal of zero-waste and we take care of our town by leaving it better than we found it ($530)
  • Printing: So that we might let our community know how to participate in the celebrations with posters and schedules ($220)
  • Space Rentals: To thank the non-profits – Mountain Theater and Mountain Heritage Museum - that donate space at severely reduced rates ($290)
  • Porta Potties: So our 4,000 participants keep the town sanitary and we don’t have to resort to actual medieval toilet practices ($2,000)
  • Insurance: So our town lets us build a 16-foot high bonfire in the center of downtown ($2,500)
  • Permit: So our town is aware and on board with our celebrations ($225)
  • Road Closures: So that we may feast and parade and celebrate in the streets ($200)
  • Liquor License: So, we can legally sell you wine and ale while you consume fantastic fresh local food at the Community Feast ($25)
  • Non-profit annual fee: To keep our organization grassroots as it should be ($10)

 You get in return for your donation:

 EVENTS

We strive to keep our events accessible to all by keeping our prices as low as we can for entry. Two of our biggest events – the Celebration of the Harvest Mother and the Trial of the Grump and Bonfire are free for all participants, yet the fire is one of our biggest expenses. 

  •  Celebration of the Harvest Mother

Vinotok Week begins at our Farmer's Market with local harvests and organic produce, meats, bread, juices, canned goods and more available. Join our booth to make your head wreaths, fill out your Grumps, get costume help, receive body art, get a schedule / info, and buy feast tickets. The Celebration of the Harvest Mother is presented by the Dance Collective and features mummers, stilt walkers, belly dancers, jesters, and forest creatures presenting a chosen, local woman as the year's Harvest Mother with live music. All past Harvest Mothers, Harvest Babies and current pregnant women of the community, are welcome to be honored.

  • Vinotok: Myth, Meaning & Ritual Workshop

Vinotok Founder and Master Storyteller Marcie Telander tells the secrets, ancient lore, origins and mystery of this community’s favorite festival and the all-community Harvest Celebration that is unlike any other in America.

  • Harvest Blessing & Mandala Creation

We create a Harvest Mandala at the Vinotok Fire Circle in a partnership with our local food organization  Mountain Roots. The mandala is a living work of art, created by participants bringing a small, nature-based token or momento of the harvest season to incorporate into the design. We honor all those who work with food and the earth – growers of vegetables, ranchers, garden volunteers, preparers and servers of our food — who provide not only for the Vinotok Community Feast, but also for sustenance in our everyday lives.

  • Goddess' Red Tent

A celebration of the goddess within every woman. A female lead and attended luxurious workshop of poetry, blessings, rune readings, storytelling and more.

  •  ​Frank Orazem Memorial Storytelling Evening 

A gathering around the  pot-bellied stove, like in the old days, to listen to stories from our town’s past. Told by favorite members of the community who honor the oral narrative of our ancestors. Our stories, like much of the west, are tied to the history of immigration and a shift in how we interact with our natural environment. This night of storytelling evokes the old timers who lived brutal lives excavating the mountains and the waves of new people who now make their lives in the same mountains. 

  • The Botsie Spritzer Memorial Liar’s Contest

A local pub is transformed by community members, the town gather to tell and hear tall tales, whoppers and adventure stories from the community with prizes for the best liar. The Green Man is announced.

  • Community Feast

A locally harvested, organic community feast. The evening begins with the ancient, non-denominational Handfasting Ceremony where couples, families, friends, partners and the entire community join in sharing vows and promises of re-commitment for a healthy, transforming future. Immediately following, the community enjoys a feast of seasonal, organic, regional and sustainably grown vegetables and meats. With a cash bar of hard apple cider, mead, wine and spiced rum. Live music by local musicians follows, wreath making station, and poetry and short story reading by local writers.

  • Mumming by the Vinotok Theatre Troupe

The cast and crew of Vinotok produce a mini theatre inside local restaurants to invite people to watch and participate in the trial of the Grump. 

  • Trial of the Grump Street Theatre

The community puts the Grump on trial with harvest maiden dances, and a play of the Harvest Mother, Dragon, Knight and Green Man. The performance is amplified and lit so the community can hear and see the tale on the temporary stage.

  •  ​Andy Bamberg Celebration Bonfire

This tradition of burning an effigy filled with the past years wrongs was first enacted by the original miners in our valley. As nonunionized workers in the early 20thcentury they were only worth their physical capacity. Once a year the mining boss would look away and allow the common people a day of protest. They would burn an image of the “boss” with impunity.

We continue this tradition with a bonfire in the center of our town, we invite everyone who danced in the streets with us and watched the Trial of the Grump to follow us and celebrate with a spectacle you will not see the like of anywhere else.

CHARACTERS

  • Harvest Mother

This goddess on Earth is chosen from the pregnant women in town. She is our symbol of fertility and grace. The center of the Vinotok troupe she determines the fate of the Grump. Dressed in white she speaks for the Earth and brings new life to us as winter approaches. 

  • The Grump

In Slovenian traditions, effigies were burned on the boss man’s lawn as a rib. These effigies have morphed into the Grump, a symbol of what we want to release from the previous year – what has blocked us.  It is giving to the flames our grievances, to make room for what we want in the new year.  This utterly unique art installation takes months to plan and prepare is unveiled only on the final night of festivities. Filled with personal written wrongs of the last year, and designed to represent the threats to our environmental, and personal freedom.

  • Green Man

Chosen as a symbol of nature, one man each year is bestowed the honor of Green Man. He must represent qualities of joy, honesty, love, wildness, and respect. He must be of community and invested in the valley’s growth and protection. He is the symbolic partner of the Harvest Mother, and leads the trial accompanied by twelve maidens.

  • Red Lady

An embodiment of a geographic location, the Red Lady is chosen by our local grassroots environmental organization to provide a human element to our mountains. Constantly under threat from those who see mountains not for their beauty but for their resources this theater of activism is essential to preserving our landscapes. This individual embodies the story of the longest successful community lead preservation campaign. Our Red Lady allows the mountain to become human so that we may never forget how important she is to our landscape and community. Embody and encourage relationship to wilderness within and without. She honors those who can’t speak for themselves; plants, animals, humans, watersheds, and mountains. 

  • The Dragon

The Dragon represents primordial, wild, unfettered nature in its most original sense.

  • The Knight

The Knight represents technology. In the beginning of the play, this technology is misused. Yet at its end, the Knight vows to protect the Red Lady, the earth and to forego his ways of thoughtless advancement

  • The Magistrate

The Magistrate represents fairness and balance

  • The Squire

A youth selected from the community to represent the future and hope of the land.

  • Supporting Characters

Vinotok’s Theatre Troupe is additionally full of 12 maidens, representing the 12 months of the year, female energy and the evolving seasons; 12 torchbearers as the male, protective energy for the town; 12 flagbearers as the markers of and holders of space; as well as a host of other Maidens, Lads, Mood Makers, Spirit Watchers, Forest Creatures, Fire Spinners, Drummers, Musicians and Dancers. 

GREEN INITIATIVES

  • Zero Waste 

As a celebration of the environment it is our responsibility to reduce our trash as much as we possibly can. For this we have a constant aspirational goal of  zero waste from our festivities that we are always working towards. We have an enormous volunteer crew we call our Green Team. They organize our recycling, compost and trash. It is not a task to take lightly and is essential to our values. We perform a grand experiment in sustainability in our microcosm. We show visitors to our valley that conscious living is possible. If we can’t do it here, where can we?

  • Green Spirit Award

A local is honored for their contribution to the wellbeing of our natural world. This takes place at The Feast and they join us for the celebration as recognized environmental crusaders.

The Impacts:

Vinotok is a community event that works to cultivate a culture of respect for our planet and our people. Our performance fosters a devotion to understanding nature where we impart the principles of protecting and preserving, as we recognizing the fragile balance of nature at the Autumn Equinox. For our people we focus on community, balance, transformation, diversity and inclusion.  

We create a space for the community to come together, feast and celebrate. Vinotok supports and promotes local and regional food producers by providing a platform for their organic labors to feed 350 people. With food grown as naturally and as locally as possible we break bread among new neighbors and old friends. Because of your donations we can ensure our farmers are paid upfront, our space guaranteed and our prices remain affordable. 

Vinotok is an active response to current issues, needs, nuances, moods and challenges both local and global. Vinotok demonstrates to the world a possibility of balance in a future that considers nature when approaching growth. Through your contributions we can continue to strive towards our zero-waste goals for nearly 4,000 participants with more efficient systems and increased oversight.  

We nurture grassroots, creative leadership within our community.We mentor each new generation, sharing our values of respect for nature and people, inclusion, diversity, transformation and balance.  We honor and foster individual creativity and vision by bringing in over 200 volunteer members of this community to offer their talents and experience. We have costume designers, sculpture builders, graphic artists, volunteer coordinators and culinary experts who all donate their time. With your donation we can free up funds raised from our events to recognize their hours of unpaid efforts with artists stipends and community acknowledgment.

Vinotok began over 34 years ago as an idea that has since generated ongoing seasonal celebrations throughout the valley. For nearly four decades we have fostered generations of Harvest Mothers and Babies. It has truly become a generational tradition. These additional funds will help our full-time community keep this our culture intact. Vinotok is a statement of who we are, what we hope to maintain, and who we constantly aspire to become.

Risks & Challenges:

We are a seven-day ceremony with events each day or evening, and over thirty individual volunteer gatherings that come together to prepare for the celebrations. Maintaining our events faces increasing challenges each year.

Having previously entirely relied on event-based funding our celebration is dependent on many variables. If it snows on our feast less people attend and we lose crucial funding. If there is music the same night as Liar’s Night, we lose revenue. As our town grows, and our insurance costs rise, and our dependence on the support of local businesses becomes uncertain, we need donations to keep our authenticity. Every year our expenses grow as more and more regulations are placed on us to provide these events to our community.

Keeping costs of participation intentionally free or very low is vital to how we operate and integral to our values. We do not want this to become an exclusive event. We need your donations and participation to make certain this remains an event for the entire community.

Vinotok is planned each year by a volunteer council of thirty active full-time residents, making decisions through consensus to overcome hurdles, tighten up our operations, and improve our celebrations. Your donations allow us to cover the basic expenses it takes to put on the week of celebrations. This takes pressure off of our events and allows our volunteers a less stressful and more sustainable experience by not relying entirely on their output for income. Extra funds allow us to support them in financial ways as they strive to provide this grassroots experience for the community.  

Your donations free up any income we make from our events to be used on unanticipated safety and permitting expenses which arise each year; improve our Zero Waste Initiative Plan; provide well-deserved Artist Honorariums for the creatives that concoct our costumes, sculptures, printed materials, and performances and more. These creatives have been generously donating their time and talent for decades of time and it’s time we are able to show them our appreciation.   

Other Ways You Can Help:

  • Volunteer!

            Come serve or prepare food at the Community Harvest Feast, help us decorate for Liar’s Night, gather natural decorations for all our events, help clean up, be a part of our Zero Waste Initiative. 

  • Attend the full week of events

            There's way more to Vinotok than just the bonfire. Begin with the Celebration of the Harvest Mother; attend A “Myth, Meaning and Ritual” workshop;bring an offering for the Harvest Blessing & Mandala Creation, womenfolk join our Goddess’ Red Tent; listen to old-timer’s yarns around the pot-bellied stove of the museum; come get wild on Liar's Night.

  • Bring your music, poetry and stories

            If you write poetry, short stories, essays, rants, songs or compose spoken word, we invite you to share your creativity at the Community Feast on Friday night, around the fire.  We also invite musicians of all kinds to bring their instruments for community jam sessions.

  • Come eat together     

            The Community Feast is generously prepared by local talent. Feast on locally and regionally grown, organic food for economic prices. Enjoy, wine, spiced rum and hard apple cider at our cash bar. In order to accomplish our Zero Waste goal no eating tools are provided, help us by bringing your own and one to share.

  • Bring your Children

           Children are welcome at Vinotok activities. Celebration of the Harvest Mother at the Farmer's Market on Sunday, the creation of the Harvest Mandala on Tuesday, Storytelling on Wednesday at the Mountain Heritage Museum, the Community Feast on Friday, and Vinotok Day are all good kid opportunities.

  • Go to dinner

           If you are not part of the mumming crew one of the best ways to experience it is to be in a restaurant on Elk Avenue from 5:00 p.m. to 7:30 p.m. on Saturday. The Vinotok Theatre Troupe perform the mumming play.  If you’re really feeling the spirit, offer the Troupe wine and bread from your table, as is the ancient tradition.

  • Wear a costume, make a head wreath, be in the streets

           Community members are encouraged to dress for any Vinotok event. Forest creatures and pan descendants also welcome. This is especially true for Liar’s Night, the Community Feast and Vinotok Day.  Make your own head wreath at the Vinotok Renaissance Booth at the Farmer's Market on Sunday (where there will also be a body art booth available), and at the Community Feast on Friday.  Grab a poet’s shirt, lace up your corset, make a jester’s hat.  

            On Vinotok Day as the mummers make their way through the restaurants, they will also be dancing in the streets. Dress up and meet them in the streets to dance to the live drums. While only the Vinotok Theatre Troupe will be mumming the restaurants, the streets should be full of community members dancing in costume.

            Vinotok is for everyone. We’ll see you in the streets.
