We the Founders
We're brothers and students at Stanford University. We founded ePluribus to better connect people and their government. ePluribus bridges the worlds of Silicon Valley and Capitol Hill to help you be heard. 

Liam and Aidan McCarty
Founders of ePluribus
Living in Silicon Valley, we know firsthand how transformative technology has been in the private sector. But most people in technology aren't thinking enough about politics and government. We started ePluribus to do what we can to make the political system work better, for everyone.
We're a team to be reckoned with. Some of our relevant accomplishments and qualifications are detailed below. You can also check out Aidan's personal website and Liam's LinkedIn page.

Aidan McCarty

 

Liam McCarty


Our Advisors
Every startup needs seasoned advisors as much as passionate founders. We're extremely proud to have Greg Rosston, Nick Troiano, and Riana Shah on our Advisory Board. Their support and expertise are invaluable.

Greg Rosston
Director of Public Policy at Stanford University
 

Nick Troiano
Executive Director of the Centrist Project
 

Riana Shah
Founder and CEO of Independent Thought & Social Action International

Why "ePluribus"?
"ePluribus" is a play on the "e-" commonly used to abbreviate "electronic," as in e-Mail or e-Commerce. "ePluribus" is also inspired by the unofficial motto of the United States "e pluribus unum", which is Latin for "out of many, one". You may not realize it, but this motto is all around you! Take out a one dollar bill and look at the back side.

"E PLURIBUS UNUM"
 
In Brief



We're brothers and students at Stanford University building an online platform to help you be heard.
We're working with a team of world-class developers and advisors to equip democracy with 21st-century tools.
ePluribus lets you turn tweets and Facebook posts into official messages to your representatives. It also provides a contact form that any website can embed to let its users talk to their representatives.
ePluribus users complete a one-time registration process that verifies their identity. This ensures that unique identity will be the new standard for civic communication, which is crucial for helping real people like you be heard.
We give representatives aggregate, non-personally identifiable data to help them process your messages. We also give some of the data to media so that they can hold your representatives accountable.

We need your help! We're raising money to make ePluribus a reality and would so appreciate your help. We'd also love it if you'd help spread the word!




What We're Building
We've spent over a year working on ePluribus to deeply understand how representatives process and understand constituent messages and how we can help them do it better. We're now extremely well equipped to do so.
ePluribus has four main components:

social media integration
embeddable widget
website
data dashboard

The following sections detail these components.
 
Social Media Integration
People routinely talk about politics on Facebook and Twitter, but it doesn't make much difference because social media is a bubble.

Our social media integration helps you break that bubble! It lets you post on Facebook or tweet on Twitter and simultaneously send an official message to your representatives. It lets you tell your friends and your representatives what you think about political issues at the same time. You simply choose a representative from a dropdown menu, and ePluribus takes the text of your post or tweet and sends it as an official message to that representative. Check out the animation below to see how it works.
 

Facebook
This is a huge deal. Social media today is the ultimate echo chamber. Stuck in our own bubbles, what we say goes only to our friends and has little impact on the outside world. ePluribus breaks the bubble so that you can be heard.
 
Embeddable Widget
The embeddable widget is a web form that any website can use to let its users send messages to their representatives. Representatives themselves can use the widget, as can news publications, blogs, government agencies, and many others. Check out the animations below for an example of how this could be used on Speaker of the House Paul Ryan's website. Notice how much easier it is to use than his current contact form!

Embeddable Widget
This is game-changing technology. When representatives embed the ePluribus widget, you'll be able to talk to them directly and finally have real impact. Other websites can also embed the widget so that you can write to your representatives anytime, anywhere. Imagine reading about the latest healthcare debate in the New York Times or the Wall Street Journal and being able to send an official message to lawmakers from the same page. ePluribus will make it easier and more impactful than ever before to talk to your government. 
 
Website
The website will allow you to send messages to multiple representatives at the same time. It will also let you see the messages you've sent, control which personal data is attached to your messages, and change your account settings. The website will be mobile-friendly and accessible on any device -- whether a desktop computer in a public library or the latest iteration of the iPhone.

Mobile-Friendly Website
 
Data Dashboard
The data dashboard is what representatives and their staff will be able to access. They'll get messages on one side and aggregate data about those messages and the people who sent them on the other side. Because ePluribus ensures unique identity and verifies personal information (see the sections below), representatives will know with certainty for the first time ever who's contacting them and what they're saying.

Data Dashboard
These four components (the social media integration, embeddable widget, website, and dashboard) make ePluribus the world's first civic network.


 
Campaign Goals
We need at least $10,000 to make ePluribus a reality. We're putting in $10,000 of our own money, not to mention the past year of hard work, so we're very much personally invested in ePluribus. 
We're running this campaign to accomplish two crucial goals:

raise as much funding as possible
reach as many people as possible

We've made it this far with grant funding we won through competitions and our own money, but now we need your help! The more funding we raise, the better ePluribus will be. The more people we reach, the more impact it will have.
Our campaign goal is $10,000. That funding will supplement the money we've already raised and will go partly toward development and partly toward marketing and service costs. We anticipate the spending breakdown to be as follows:


$5,000: additional development of social media integration, optimization of virality, Safari extension (in addition to Chrome)

$3,500: marketing of social media integration and embeddable widget, Facebook and Twitter ads

$1,500: embeddable widget service costs (for major publishers), data dashboard service costs

We hope to raise far more than $10,000 if at all possible because we can do so much more if we have more resources. Here are a few of our stretch goals:


with $20,000 total: dedicated salesperson, deals with online media and representatives, validation of business model, additional online marketing

with $50,000 total: dedicated part-time developer for all technical needs and product iteration, furthering of development timeline as described below, additional online and analog marketing

with $100,000 total: dedicated full-time developer to prepare for large user base and iterate product along development timeline below, significant additional marketing


 
Perks!
We're so grateful for your support and we want to give you something personal and special for it. We've prepared some amazing perks for you to choose from. Feel free to ask us any questions you may have about them!


$500 - The Kitchen Sink: If you give $500 or more, you'll receive ALL of our other perks, without question. This includes a personalized video spot, your picture in our next video, Liam's book, exclusive early access, your name on our "We the People" page, and a heartfelt thank you. If you donate the most, you may even be our John Hancock! (See the "We the People" perk for more information.)

$200 - Personalized Video Spot: Check out this 15-second video of our social media integration. We'll make a personalized version of this video so that you can show it off to your friends! You'll be the person sending the message in the video, and you can choose what you want to say and which representative want to send it to. We can even use your footage if you send us about 30 seconds of video. There are only 10 available so act soon!




$100 - Your Picture in One of Our Videos: At the end of our campaign video, we have a series of pictures of people with the phrase "out of many" superimposed. We'll put your picture in our next video! And we'll send you the video and tell you when you appear. There are only 25 available so act soon!
$50 - Liam's Book, Data and Power: You'll receive a copy of Liam's book, which explores issues of big data and modern America. We're extremely wary of data privacy concerns and take the utmost care with your personal data; this book explains exactly why.

$25 - Exclusive Early Access: You can be one of the first people in the world to use ePluribus! You'll be able to try it out before anyone else, and will be first in line to tell us how we can make our product even better. This perk is exclusive to this campaign and will not be offered outside of it. Get it while you can!

$10 - Your Name on Our Website's "We the People" Page: If you contribute at least $10, we'll put your name on our "We the People" page, which you'll be able to see on our website. The more you contribute, the bigger you name will be! The person who contributes the most will be the John Hancock of our page: their name will be much bigger than everyone else's. See if you can be our John Hancock!


$1 - Every Dollar Counts: Seriously. Every single dollar is enormously appreciated. We are building ePluribus to help people like you to be heard, and we couldn't do it without you. We'll send you a heartfelt thank you for your support.


Problem

The real problem we're addressing may not be obvious. It's that representatives can't process, let alone understand, the enormous number of messages they receive. Because of this, the solution is not to send more messages but rather to send better messages: ones that representatives can process and understand.
One of the hardest things about civic tech is remembering what the problem isn't. Here's a list:


It's not that we need better access to information. Anyone who wants to read a bill, see information about their representatives, or learn about how government works can do so very easily with the help of a huge number of resources. Even the most obsessed political junkie would never run out of information.

It's not that sending messages to representatives is hard. Sending messages is easy; being heard is hard. It isn't very difficult to fill out a contact form, make a phone call, or even send a letter or fax. The problem is that none of these traditional channels give you any impact. 


It's not that people don't care about politics. People talk about politics, protest, and petition all the time. Sure, some people are apathetic, but there have always been a huge number of people who care deeply about politics, and there always will be. Particularly following the most recent election cycle, more and more people are engaging with the political system.


Like most people working on civic technology, we cycled through these problems-that-aren't-really-problems until we learned better. Through our research, we identified what the problem truly is: it's that civic communication lacks unique identity, which is why you have no impact. When you send a message to your representative, they don't even know for sure if you're their constituent or if you're a unique person. They know nothing about you and can't process your message is a meaningful way. Meanwhile, advocacy groups flood representatives with thousands of messages. No wonder contacting representatives doesn't work: your voice is drowned out in the crowd.
We're building ePluribus to make unique identity the new standard for civic communication. You'll complete a simple, easy, one-time registration process to verify that you're a person (not a bot), a unique person with one account, and that you're the person you say you are. It's no different than signing up for a bank account. You expect your bank to make sure you're actually you, and with ePluribus you can expect the same from your representatives.


Why Is This New?
Our emphasis on unique identity is completely new. Everyone else is building bigger loudspeakers, but volume is the problem not the solution. We're not building any kind of loudspeaker. We're building a direct line to your representatives so that you won't have to shout to be heard.
Civic technology has for the past couple decades focused mainly on two areas:

making it very easy for people to contact representatives in traditional ways (all of which lack unique identity)
giving lobbyists and special interests high tech tools that make it worse for the average American, not better

Both of these make civic communication worse, not better. The first one ironically makes it even harder to be heard: the number of messages representatives receive has increased at least 10x, but the technology to process and understand those messages has hardly improved. The second only helps big money get bigger: most Americans are completely left out of the loop.
Strangely, advocacy groups are a big part of the problem. Let's say you run an advocacy group, and you run an online petition campaign to show support. If you get 25,000 clicks on your petition, you don't care if those clicks came from 25,000 unique people or just 1,000. Even if you know they came from only 1,000 people, you certainly won't tell anyone else! It looks like you have more support than you actually do, and that helps your cause.
This is an extremely problematic incentive: it makes it impossible for representatives to know where support really lies. What are they supposed to make of online petitions and mass mailings? How are they supposed to hear real people with real concerns who send them individual messages? They can't because those messages are buried in the avalanche of communications advocacy groups are sending them every hour of every day. No wonder we don't like what our representatives represent: they're not representing us!
Unique identity is the clear solution to this problem. With the help of ePluribus, representatives will know that the people contacting them are real people with only one account. They'll finally be able to listen to you and tune out the noise, and you'll finally be heard. Advocacy will be meaningful again.
 
Why Us?
Civic technology is hard to do well. To build the product, you need to work with people in technology who generally know nothing about politics. To make the product matter, you need to work with people in politics who generally know nothing about technology. And to get the product used, you need to work with people all over the country who often don't know much about either.

There aren't many people with the right skills, backgrounds, and professional networks to create such a product successfully. But we're just those people. story:
This Year’s Goal: Cover the Fest!

Help take our Not-For-Profit Society a step closer to self sustainability!

An important step in becoming more sustainable is reducing our yearly rental overhead. This year's crowdfunding cause is focused on just that, specifically purchasing our own tents! 

In four short years, Bear Creek Folk Festival has quickly become a treasure of the Arts and Culture landscape of Grande Prairie. Proudly presenting world-class lineups every year, including artists such as Feist, Blue Rodeo, case/lang/veirs (Neko Case, k.d. lang, and Laura Veirs), Bruce Cockburn, Alan Doyle, Corb Lund, City and Colour, Colin James, Michael Franti and Spearhead, and many more, and drawing crowds of thousands from all around Western Canada and beyond, it is exciting to think of the legacy event that this festival is poised to become. Additionally, we are working to become more sustainable and cut down on our yearly overhead. To this end, we are raising funds to help “Cover the Fest!” and purchase our own tents to cut down on the thousands of dollars in annual rental costs for our current tent needs.

The tents we want to purchase are the beautiful, high-peaked, white, wind-resistant tents that you have grown used to seeing on our site every year. Over time, we aim to own all of our own tents site-wide. This would make a big difference to our annual financial stability. We are excited to finally take the first step towards this important goal through this funding campaign!

Be part of history in the making and help us to not only make 2021 a year to remember, but also build the foundation to become stronger and more sustainable! Twenty years from now, when this festival has become an important mainstay in Alberta's rich cultural landscape, you can proudly say that you helped to make it happen!

The Event

The 2021 Bear Creek Folk Fest will take place August 13-15 on a picturesque hill in Muskoseepi Park, in Grande Prairie. The festival features over 30 artists from around the world, performing in multiple workshops and concerts, on four stages over three days. The music ranges from traditional folk to blues, country, Celtic, rock, and many points in between, and features a great combination of world-famous headliners, emerging artists, and undiscovered gems.

First and foremost, this is an inclusive and family-friendly event. Children under 12 and seniors 80 and over are free. This year will mark a special expansion of our very popular kids area with the launch of our “Kids Zone Fest within a Fest” and the addition of children’s performers and other programming. 

The site also features an artisan crafts area, food vendors from around Western Canada, and a beer garden with sight lines to the  main stage.

Many will attest that this is a magical weekend. Everywhere you turn, you see friendly volunteers, families gathering, old friends reuniting, and new friendships being formed. It is truly the gathering and creation of a community.

This year marks new challenges and uncertainties as we all work to overcome the COVID pandemic. We are committed to continuing to be a safe and friendly environment for all festival participants and are taking major steps to ensure that we are prepared to present a fantastic event in 2021. It will be both a celebration of world-class family entertainment worthy of our Fifth Anniversary and an event that is safe and accessible to all, one that will adhere to any and all public health guidelines that may exist at the time of our event.

This has been a difficult time for people around the world. We look forward to playing an integral role in drawing our community back together and breathing new life into our local economy, local tourism, and civic morale. 

The Goal

The first $7,000 of our goal will buy us the tents needed for our newly expanded Kids Zone. Funds we raise beyond that would cover the cost of our Snack Shack tent, Beer Garden shade tent and volunteer shade tents. Though we have set a fundraising goal of $15,000, the more tents we are able to buy through this campaign, the more secure and sustainable the fest will become!  

To show our gratitude, we are offering tokens of appreciation for each funding level. These are special promotions that will not be available beyond this campaign. For the first time ever, we are also offering the opportunity to purchase and dedicate a particular tent and have your own legacy that lives on our site. More than anything, years from now, you can be proud that you were one of the people that supported this great event and helped to create a legacy.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not in a position to give financially, you can still help! For anyone who is a fan of the festival or excited to give it a try, please spread the word about this campaign and encourage those who can participate to do so. Even the smallest of contributions can add up to make a huge difference!

story:
Do you want an ice cream exhibition to launch in London this summer? The British Museum of Food is announcing a crowdfunding page to bring the first major exhibition that explores the history and sensory pleasure of the nation’s favourite summertime treat, ice cream, to the capital.

The campaign is being fronted by museum founders Bompas & Parr. If you pledge to make the exhibition happen, not only will you have free tickets to SCOOP: The Wonderful World of Ice Cream, but your name will feature on the Patron’s Wall of Frozen Fame. Other prizes include having your face made into ice cream, and even having ice cream for breakfast with Sam Bompas and Harry Parr in five years time. 

SCOOP will open at the height of summer for three months if the crowdfunding target is reached and will feature the world’s largest collection of historic ice cream paraphernalia. This never-before-exhibited collection will be drawn from 14,000 vintage equipment, service-ware, advertising, and music collected over 40 years by Robin and Caroline Weir ranging from Victorian ice cream moulds to an Andy Warhol print. Robin and Caroline Weir are the authors of the award-winning book — "Ice Creams Sorbets and Gelati: The Definitive Guide" from Grub Street Publishers.

The exhibition will coincide with the 300th anniversary of Mary Eales’ Receipts (1718), the first printed volume to feature ice cream in an English publication and the 399th anniversary of the first ice house built in Britain (to make ice cream) in Greenwich Park by order of James I.

A special feature of this exhibition will be a focus on the life and ingenuity of Agnes B. Marshall, known in Victorian times as the Queen of Ices. Far ahead of her time, Marshall wrote several successful cook books, patented an ice cream machine and even suggested using liquid nitrogen to make ice cream as early as the late 1800s. Visitors will get to ‘meet’ Agnes’s amanuensis as part of an immersive and interactive theatre performance. Heston Blumenthal, recipient of multiple Michelin stars, called Marshall: “one of the greatest culinary pioneers this country has ever seen.”

SCOOP: The Wonderful World of Ice Cream will further include curated galleries, and a programme of talks, events, workshops and wonders including real glacial ice, ice cream weather and glow-in-the-dark ice cream. More details will be announced pending the success of the Indiegogo campaign. 

 

About the British Museum of Food

In November 2015 Bompas & Parr opened the British Museum of Food, the world’s first dedicated cultural institution entirely devoted to the history, evolution, science and art of food. For three months, the museum presented a series of exhibits that aligned with the quirky and disruptive style of the studio’s approach to communicating food and drink, coupled with the mission, ethos and values of a new national museum open to everyone.

Located at a temporary site at London’s Borough Market, Bompas & Parr collaborated with the market’s managers, trustees and traders alongside artists and scientists to initiate a new cultural institution for the capital.

From a cinematic journey that positioned the audience as the food on the end of a fork and followed its journey into the body, to a chocolate research project hosted in an anechoic chamber and a temperature and humidity-controlled butterfly house, the exhibits were multi-sensory and multi-disciplinary explorations of the significance of food in our lives. In addition, the museum presented traditional museum showcases, including a gallery of disruptive food artworks and an archive of food and drink menus stretching nearly 300 years.

The museum's aspirations, as it seeks a permanent home, are to change people’s lives by helping them refocus their attention on what they eat and to recognise the ways in which food impacts our culture, politics, economy and history.

A multi-sensory and experiential space, the museum is committed to developing new forms of participatory art/science projects designed to provoke new thinking, spark curiosity and inspire wonder about humankind’s responses – past, present and future – of one of our basic, fundamental needs: the need to eat.

www.bmof.org

About Bompas & Parr

Bompas & Parr is globally recognised as the leading expert in multi-sensory experience design. The studio works with commercial brands, artistic institutions, private clients and governments to deliver emotionally compelling experiences to a wide variety of audiences. 

Sam Bompas and Harry Parr first came to prominence through their expertise in jelly-making, but the business rapidly grew into a fully-fledged creative studio offering food and drink design, brand consultancy and immersive experiences across a diverse number of industries. 

The founders’ backgrounds in marketing and architecture play a key role in the positioning and nature of the studio’s output and, along with a diverse spread of talents among the 20-strong team, Bompas & Parr activations boast a bold ambition, distinct aesthetic style and interpretive vigour that’s unrivalled among creative agencies. The studio works to experiment, develop and produce projects and experiences as well as provide strategy, analysis and advice for brands to increase consumer engagement through experience design. 

Genre-defining projects include Alcoholic Architecture, an inhabitable cloud of gin and tonic; the world’s first Multi-Sensory Fireworks display for London New Year’s Eve 2013; and the Taste Experience for the Guinness Storehouse in Dublin.

Bompas & Parr works with brands such as Coca-Cola, Johnnie Walker, Mercedes, Vodafone, and LVMH as well as cultural institutions such as The Barbican, San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and The Garage Museum of Contemporary Art, Moscow.  

The studio is based in south London but in the past year has realised projects on practically every continent. 

www.bompasandparr.com

story:
We want to provide a safe and supportive environment for our member artists, communities that access our space and  audiences who attend our events.

Over the past 4 years we have refurbished a 5500 sq ft industrial building into a modern artist studio with studio spaces, large build workshop, photography darkroom, screen-printing darkroom and facilities, print area, project room, electronics area, meeting room and artist library. We have invested thousands of euros of personal capital, thousands of hours of sweat equity and reinvested the majority of  membership fees paid to us into the building. Now we need a little bit of help from the outside.

During 2017 we focused a lot of time in securing a long term lease for the building to ensure that value for money was guaranteed when investing into the building itself. In Jan 2018 we secured a 10 year lease and this means for the next 10 years we can confidently continue to provide safe and affordable studio space to artists working in Dublin. That's only 50c per year for each fiver donated!

 

A4 Sounds is an interdisciplinary artist studio and gallery. We provide affordable access to studio space, artist facilities and workshops and courses. We curate a programme of art events including artist residencies, graduate awards, exhibitions, community get togethers, talks, and cinema, performance and music events. We also work with a wide range of communities, supporting them in their work through either provision of space or equipment for example The Forgotten Zine Archive, BLEND Residents Association, Fire House Film Contest, Hackfest Animation Festival, Abortion Rights Campaign, Strike 4 Repeal, the home-work collective and Irish Housing Network.

 

A4 is an important resource for numerous artists, activists, groups and collectives in Dublin City. We provide an alternative model for studio space that focuses on shared facilities and resources. This means we can support more artists at a lower cost compared to the more traditional model of a desk in a room. Currently we are the most affordable artist led studio in the city which is extremely important considering the rising prices of rent and living costs which are forcing many artists to leave.


Since opening our doors 4 years ago we have:

  1. Supported hundreds of artists and many communities and activist groups.
  2. Developed an artist in residency programme supporting 2-3 artists from studio work to exhibition each year.
  3. Developed our Graduate Award supporting 1 graduate from DIT Grangegorman each year.
  4. Developed our Supported Project Award supporting 1-5 activist groups each year.
  5. Developed our educational programme, providing low cost access to learning for the public and providing employment opportunities for our member artists.
  6. Helped fundraise for a number of causes and organisations.
  7. Curated a wide range of events and exhibitions.

story:
Ítaca Librería-Bar

Será una librería con énfasis en editoriales independientes y con especial atención a todo el espectro de la literatura latinoamericana. Tendremos una escuela para libreros y editores, una residencia artística y será el primer bar donde los cocteles tendrán el nombre que elijan sus visitantes.


Prólogo

Yo, Rodnei Casares, soy librero, amo la experiencia del libro físico, promuevo la lectura, le doy valor al espacio en el que los lectores se reconocen y se encuentran a gusto, quiero que mis hijos vivan la experiencia lectora que solo se da en una librería. Sé que las librerías como las conocíamos no pueden sostenerse por sí solas, por eso propongo elevar la experiencia y darle a la comunidad un lugar no solo donde puedas comprar un libro. Los tiempos cambiaron, por eso haré de este, un lugar de reunión, educativo y recreativo. Conozco a los lectores, soy uno de ellos.

 

Mi motivación

Durante 15 años estuve a cargo de la mejor librería independiente de Venezuela, devoraba cualquier libro que cayera en mis manos, pero sentía que faltaba algo en los libros en los que me perdía.

Siempre estuvo en mí la idea de fundar una librería, pero fue en diciembre de 2016 cuando tuve por primera vez el pensamiento que se convertiría en Ítaca Librería-Bar. Con un trago que preparé en mi casa y que bauticé con el nombre de una poeta venezolana me dije que sería genial poder sumar dos de mis pasiones.
 

La escuela de libreros

Lo que más me emociona de este proyecto es poder fundar una escuela para libreros. Es muy difícil en Latinoamérica formarse en el oficio, hay algunos espacios de pero no son suficientes, mi formación en su mayoría fue de forma empírica y por algunos cursos que dictó el CERLALC.

Ya lo dijo Romano Montroni en su libro Vender el alma: "¿Qué es un buen librero? Es una persona consciente de que  no vende una mercancía cualquiera, sino algo que posee una calidad particular". 
Queremos libreros capaces de dar respuestas, esta es la oportunidad de tenerlos.

 

Mi experiencia

Por muchos años he estado visitando librerías, mi trabajo no se ha quedado en los espacios que he regentado, también he conversado con muchos colegas sobre lo que quisieran de sus espacios, necesitas de mucha pasión pero también de buenas ideas para levantar un lugar donde la gente se sienta a gusto, es lo que haremos con Ítaca Librería-Bar.

Al crear Ítaca no solo vamos a emparejar libros y bebidas, queremos que la gente se vea reflejada en todo el espectro de la experiencia y la imaginación humana.

Ítaca Libros Bar será una librería de propiedad venezolana de Medellín, Colombia, que venderá literatura latinoamericana variada.  Será un lugar para pasear por los estantes, que tendrán, gracias a ustedes, cada uno una historia. Tomar un café o un mojito, beber una copa de vino o una cerveza. Ítaca tendrá clubes de lectura, eventos de autores y horas de cuentos.

Comienza la búsqueda

Decidí que si iba a abrir una librería llena de literatura latinoamericana, con editoriales independientes necesitaba conocer más autores latinos y editoriales de este tipo. Así que empecé a investigar desde 2017, visité ferias internaciones y creé redes para conectar con autores y lectores a través de varios de mis proyectos.


 

 El salto al agua

Durante mucho tiempo pensé en subir el proyecto a esta plataforma pero siempre me detenía por alguna razón, fue hasta el 13 de abril que después de un tuit que se hizo viral tomé la decisión de lanzarme al agua. Ítaca será un homenaje a todas las librerías caídas.
E
 

¿Por qué en Colombia?

Aquí tomo prestadas las palabras de María González de León:

“Todos queremos volver a casa, a Ítaca, avistar desde el mar la isla en la que crecimos, volver a ver a la mujer que amamos y que nos espera hace tantos años. Por esta razón, la legendaria isla griega —hogar de Odiseo, Penélope y Telémaco— es la metáfora perfecta del propósito de la vida, de eso que nunca dejaremos de perseguir.

Las Ítacas pueden ser, entonces, casi cualquier cosa: podrían representar el proceso para lograr una meta o para recuperar algo que hemos perdido, incluso, podrían simbolizar el acto de transitar por la vida de principio a fin, para finalmente volver al origen”.

 

Y nunca olvidar estas líneas de Kavafis:

 

Ten siempre a Ítaca en tu mente.

Llegar allí es tu destino.

Mas no apresures nunca el viaje.

Mejor que dure muchos años

y atracar, viejo ya, en la isla,

enriquecido de cuanto ganaste en el camino

sin aguantar a que Ítaca te enriquezca.

 

Ítaca te brindó tan hermoso viaje.

Sin ella no habrías emprendido el camino.

Pero no tiene ya nada que darte.

story:
About Lost Property Arts Collective

Lost Property is a not-for-profit Community Interest Company with background in experimental and improvised music, sound and art. We are a group made up of individuals devoted to our creative endeavours and devising memorable events for curious people.

In 2013 we joined forces to realise the first Fort Process festival, and since then have staged some acclaimed events, such as our retrospective concerts of Terry Riley and Alvin Lucier, the film season Lumen, and our workshops in areas such as gamelan and field recording. The second Fort Process was another great success, held in 2016.

 

Fort Process

Fort Process is a unique festival that has grown to establish an important place on the UK experimental events calendar. It is held within Newhaven Fort, a 19th century structure built to protect the coast of Newhaven, East Sussex. This site offers a dizzying number of spaces of all shapes and sizes, each possessing a unique sonic and visual character. There are tunnels, arches and caverns that draw visitors through the ground itself and into the depths of the interior. These possess rich resonant and reverberant acoustics. The exterior features numerous fortifications dotted over the grasslands, some facing out across the English channel. In every case the setting provides a remarkably unconventional backdrop for installations, performances and interactive experiences.

Fort Process is as much about the journey as it is about the individual acts on the programme. Festival goers have an opportunity to explore the grounds throughout the day, uncovering more and more as they go. 

Our curation offers opportunities to national and international artists working at all levels; we work with young, emerging creators as well as high profile names whose influence spans decades, and we involve a significant number of locals, showcasing the talents of those living and working in the East Sussex area. The festival also helps draw attention to Newhaven, a quiet port town that links the UK with the continent. 

More information on the festival can be found on our website: http://fortprocess.co.uk 

 

What's the deal?

We need to raise some funds as part of our arrangement with Arts Council England, so we're doing it in a way that offers you some bargains and rather special Fort Process memorabilia. This extra funding will help us execute an amazing festival. Items on offer include:

  • T-shirts and tote bags: a new look to match the 2018 event theme, these are hand screen printed in Brighton and are available in various sizes.
     
  • Great ticket bundle deals: with these deals you can save money on the standard ticket price and bring along friends and family.
     
  • Workshops - we are offering tickets to the Tasos Stamou instrument building workshop that is scheduled for 23rd September in Newhaven, the day after the main event.  
     
  • Fort Processor synths: these have been designed and built especially for the festival by Tim Drage and Lisa McKendrick, taking their visual design from the shape of the site itself. They are available as DIY PCB circuits, with fully built synths available too. The design progress is being published on their blog here; https://isntses.weebly.com/blog   Please note that as this is a newly developed model there may be some difference between the plans they have posted and the finished  item.

Our curation offers opportunities to national and international artists working at all levels; we work with young, emerging creators as well as high profile names whose influence spans decades, and we involve a significant number of locals, showcasing the talents of those living and working in the East Sussex area. The festival also helps draw attention to Newhaven, a quiet port town that links the UK with the continent. 
More information on the festival can be found on our website: http://fortprocess.co.uk 
 

What's the deal?
We need to raise some funds as part of our arrangement with Arts Council England, so we're doing it in a way that offers you some bargains and rather special Fort Process memorabilia. This extra funding will help us execute an amazing festival. Items on offer include:

T-shirts and tote bags: a new look to match the 2018 event theme, these are hand screen printed in Brighton and are available in various sizes. 
Great ticket bundle deals: with these deals you can save money on the standard ticket price and bring along friends and family. 
Workshops - we are offering tickets to the Tasos Stamou instrument building workshop that is scheduled for 23rd September in Newhaven, the day after the main event.   
Fort Processor synths: these have been designed and built especially for the festival by Tim Drage and Lisa McKendrick, taking their visual design from the shape of the site itself. They are available as DIY PCB circuits, with fully built synths available too. The design progress is being published on their blog here; https://isntses.weebly.com/blog   Please note that as this is a newly developed model there may be some difference between the plans they have posted and the finished  item.

story:
Short Summary

We are the oldest international theatre organisation in the world, the Union Internationale de la Marionnette (UNIMA), a Non-Governmental Organization affiliated to UNESCO. Our association is made up of a vast body of people (more than 7000 members), coming from all over the world, who believe in puppetry and human values, and whose aim is to promote the art of puppetry. 

We are entering a very special year for our association: UNIMA's 90th anniversary. We must celebrate its long history, as a tribute to our founders and there is no a better way to do it than working together with the new generations,  to make known our history, our heritage and therefore, be able to think about the future.

Today, two main axes of the organization are reflected into these two events:

  • Youth, with a project named “4 Creations, 4 continents”
  • Heritage, with an exposition called “People & Puppets. UNIMA: Believing in and Creating a Common Future for Puppetry (1929 - 2019)” and the edition of the book, the catalogue of the exhibition: The History of UNIMA.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Dear friends of puppetry world, Dear colleagues,

To achieve our goal, to be able to develop the projects we have in mind, we need your help, we need your support. The cost of these two events is not as expensive as it could be but we need more money than we have, and even though we are getting some special grants from French and Spanish Institutions, still it is not enough, we need more money. Therefore, WE COUNT ON YOU. We have set a goal to reach 20.000€. Your contributions will help us a lot to carry out these two huge projects. On one hand, the staging of the work "Customs" that will be done by young people coming from different countries, different cultures, having a unique experience full of values like cooperation, integration, interculturalism, universalism, mutual understanding and peace. On the other hand, the exhibition “People & Puppets. UNIMA: Believing in and Creating a Common Future for Puppetry (1929 - 2019)” that will help to keep alive a long puppetry history and to show it to a wide audience.

UNIMA is generous and, especially during this year of anniversary, likes to recognize those that help the organization, so we have designed these original perks related to UNIMA  and puppetry world. We hope you will like them:

  • UNIMA Screen saver
  • UNIMA 90th Anniversary Poster
  • UNIMA Totebag
  • UNIMA Magnet
  •  VIP access and guided tour to the exhibition “People & Puppets. UNIMA: Believing in and Creating a Common Future for Puppetry (1929 - 2019)” during the FMTM in Charleville- Mézières, France. (Date to be confirmed: from 20 to 29 September)
  • Finger puppet collection
  • Shadow collector puppet: Specially designed, handmade and painted in leather by Andhra Pradesh, shadow puppeter from India.
  • Limited edition numbered illustration

 

The Impact

As mentioned before we are now focusing the activity of our association on two fundamental pillars:

Youth

We want to point out the importance of the values and ideas of universalism, openness and cooperation, which have been promoted since the creation of our association in 1929, and to emphasize its relevance.

To do this, we are creating the project: 4 creations, 4 continents

The five geographical zones, joined in four, that make up UNIMA (Europe, America, Asia-Pacific and Africa) will propose a different version of the same story, using puppets. Each zone will be represented by schools and / or young puppeteers that will work together coming from different countries in their continent and will create an original production.

They will work on the same scenario, CUSTOMS, of the young Brazilian puppeteer Marcos Nicolaïewsky, who was selected by the international jury, last September in Charleville-Mézières. Marcos shares UNIMA's desire to eliminate borders and spread common values for peace and art.

The four creations will be presented at the next UNIMA Congress in Bali, in 2020, giving all people there the possibility of appreciating how the same work can be interpreted depending on where you are coming from.

The objective of this initiative is to emphasize the importance of values like cooperation, integration, interculturalism, universalism, mutual understanding, and peace… through puppetry art

 

Heritage

On the era of the technology we must preserve our roots, our history, OUR ANCESTRAL ART. We must not forget that puppetry is one of the oldest art. The art that became the founding element of many theatrical adventures of the 20th and 21st centuries...

Our goal is to make visible the evolution and progress of the puppetry arts throughout the history of those who have "made" UNIMA.

For this, our organization carries out the exhibition project: “People & Puppets. UNIMA: Believing in and Creating a Common Future for Puppetry (1929 - 2019)”. An exhibition in which we will be able to see the history of puppetry

Through this exhibition, one can see what an important role UNIMA has played and continues to play in the world of puppetry – from the development of the medium, to training new puppeteers and preserving the old traditions, and spreading puppetry from one continent to the other.

UNIMA has played a very important and critical role in bringing together puppeteers from all over the world.  This exhibition highlights that role, showing how many countries in which UNIMA has National Centers, keep puppetry alive, and help puppeteers and local talent to achieve their objectives.

With this exhibition, UNIMA will also pay tribute to the important Individuals who believed in puppetry, and were able to create a Common Future for all of us. We, those that are the successors of our founders, are obliged to continue bringing the torch forward as they do in the Olympic Games. We cannot let this bright fire extinguish, we must keep the fire alive for the future generations, and keep the emotions alive, so that this millennial art will continue living and flourish year after year.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We are such a big community, all type of help to preserve this ancestral art will be more than welcome.

We would very much appreciate if you could share this iniciative in your circles!

THANK YOU ALL

 

Long Life to Puppetry, Long Life to Puppeteers, Long Life to UNIMA!!!!

story:
Emily is currently in Kathmandu, the capital of Nepal. These are her words, and her pictures.

"We have found a small team of workers, a small NGO working without any machinery or tools in a particularly badly hit area. Today they have pulled out 3 survivors. One 8 year old boy, still alive. Many dead bodies. We have a group of travellers who are going to help tomorrow. I'll keep you updated. I'm trying to figure out if there's a way of collecting some money to help this team, and other teams/ people in need. If anyone has any advice on how to do this quickly please let me now.

The aftershocks are continuing , we just had another strong one.

There is still hope of finding survivors."

This money is being sent out to Emily directly, to fund the tools she needs to assist with recovering survivors from the rubble, and the ongoing efforts to provide food, water, shelter and emergency aid in Kathmandu.

Update - 30th April 2015

"Operation distribution of supplies is underway! I'm teaming up with a big group of volunteers, a great and well organised network of people basing themselves at a hostel called yellow house. I was starting to feel a little overwhelmed and exhausted from the massive task of concocting an effective plan of action, on my own. The complexity of the situation can send you round in circles. People in villages are already fighting over food and shelter. To turn up somewhere with less tarpaulin or food than needed, can serve to make problems worse. This is just one issue. Having found this group today, i now feel very optimistic about the situation. 
I have bought enough tarpaulins and rope to shelter 60 families or so. I have managed to find 30 kg of rice, I'm going back later today to buy more. Most of the tarpaulin shops have been partially destroyed in the earthquake, so are closed. I was very lucky to eventually find a place with crumbling walls, hidden down tiny backalleys and through alittle brick tunnel. An element of chaos as the customers frantically bought up the stock, before they closed the doors for the forseeable future. The building isn't safe to be around. It is possible to order some with another company, but much more expensive.
An amazingly strong nepali lad cycled the mass of stuff for miles through the city at great speed, in the blazing sun. With me legging it alongside. Very impressive.
We all meet tomorrow at 8, different parties going to different villages depending on supplies and need. I'll let you know the breakdown of funds spent a little bit later."

Update: 6th May 2015

Breakdown of funds spent:
Rice 1830kg - £505.38
Tents- £193.88
Rope- £13.57
Sanitiser/water etc- £32.96
Various transport- £14.54
= £760.33
I will transfer the left over £240 to our team Nepal Grassroots Recovery today. It will be spent on shelter/rice. 
Thank you so much.

story:
Celebrate 5 Years, Help us Rebuild & Be Strong for 5 More!

Favianna Rodriguez and I opened SoleSpace five years ago this month as an antidote to the displacement we saw changing Oakland - we set out to celebrate and strengthen The Town's homegrown culture and the spirit of creative resistance by regularly hosting artists and dynamic community events...

Now after hosting 520+ such events, we urgently need to replace the floor - plus our broken sound system, projector, and several broken displays.

At the same time, we’re facing a David-and-Goliath battle with the mega-corporate shoe chain that moved in this summer right up the street. They’ve wasted no time flexing the muscle that comes with owning 120+ stores across 8 states.

Help us strengthen & rebuild SoleSpace's infrastructure so we can continue to serve the community and survive in this increasingly competitive environment.

We need to raise $10,000 so we can keep the original SoleSpace functioning as a high-quality community event space for 5 more years - and beyond, into the future.

Back this campaign so we can #KeepSoleSpaceStrong and host lots more community events for 5 more years...and beyond!

* If you prefer to Make a no interest KIVA loan rather than donate for a perk, Click here, 

Photo: Brooke Anderson

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $10,000 on IndieGoGo to rebuild & strengthen SoleSpace.

That's 300 people giving an average of $33.34 - some more, some less. 

We Can Do This. More than 300 people per week come through our doors.

Chip in to get our undying appreciation PLUS lots of AMAZING perks:

  • Exclusive tix to "Stars of SoleSpace" our event series + meet-and-greet featuring Jeff Chang, Adrienne Maree Brown, Adam Mansbach, Chinaka Hodge, Josh Healey & many more.
  • Art & Books by kickass Oakland artists and authors you know and love 
  • Limited edition SoleSpace tee shirts & bags
  • Discounted event rentals for family parties & school or non-profit fundraisers 
  • Much more...

The Impact: This Pic Says It All!

Other Ways You Can Help

Well, we really need you to give money, to donate to this campaign.

Once you've done that, or if you really can't, please help us reach our goal by:

  • Post & Re-Post this campaign! Add your own testimonial!
  • Use Indiegogo's share tools & your own crafty social media skills
  • Add a video clip or comments on why we should "Keep SoleSpace Strong"

Thank you for considering this request. For reals.

Please send questions, suggestions, & critiques: infoATsolespace.com

story:
Overview

Celebrating the Asian American LGBTQ+ Experience is an annual community event founded by author CB Lee that brings together LGBTQ+ Asian Americans for an evening of discussion, performances, and audience Q&A in historic downtown Los Angeles as part of Lambda Litfest. This year's event takes place on September 27, 2019 at the Chinese American Museum with Kay Ulunday Barrett, Nick Dong, Addie Tsai, Henry Lien, and Muriel Leung, moderated by CB Lee, and is free to the public.

WHY LGBTQ+ ASIAN AMERICAN EVENTS?

Hello! I’m CB Lee, author of the SIDEKICK SQUAD series. As a queer Chinese-Vietnamese American, growing up, I felt pretty isolated and unsure of who I was, as part of the LGBTQ+ community and growing up as part of multiple cultures. Maya Reddy states in the Mission Statement of the Gaysian Project, “When we are not seen, we are not known. That sense of loneliness is overpowering. Rarely are all Asian ethnicities recognized. And just as rarely are all identities of queerness celebrated, especially within Asian American representation.”  Representation is just a small part of this event—it’s about creating and fostering community.

 As a writer, I seek to tell stories that not only entertain but also inspire others and show inclusive characters who reflect the world we live in. In 2017, I curated the first iteration of this event in partnership with the Chinese American Museum, and was overwhelmed by the amount of amazing people who turned up for what I thought would be a modest reading and panel. Instead, the CAM courtyard overflowed with community and people who came together to see our performers, explore the exhibits and participate in a lively discussion. This year, with your support, I’m hoping to create a unique and enriching experience for the community, working with the Chinese American Museum and the Gaysian Project to encourage people to explore the amazing exhibits at the museum and also participate in an evening of discussion.

CELEBRASIANQ seeks to bring together Asian Americans in the LGBTQ+ community with events that celebrate who they are in a space that inspires creativity, conversation and celebration.

 

 

 

2019: CELEBRATING THE ASIAN AMERICAN LGBTQ+ EXPERIENCE

 

CELEBRATING THE ASIAN AMERICAN LGBTQ+ EXPERIENCE brings together Asian American artists, writers, and creative industry professionals in the LGBTQ+ community in historic downtown Los Angeles at the Chinese American Museum for Lambda Literary’s LitFest 2019 for an evening of community and celebrating art and creativity. CAM’s current exhibition, “Lightscapes: Reenvisioning the Shanshuihua,” reimagines the philosophies of Chinese landscape paintings with new media and immersive light-based installations. The masters of Chinese landscape art would often retreat to nature to examine the themes of harmony and balance in the cosmos, as well as find sanctuary in nature. For the LGBTQ+ community, finding balance and safety to express ourselves is one of the challenges of everyday life. Where do we go as a community to retreat and how do we find balance in our lives?

Lambda Literary and CAM invite you to join us for an evening of special performances, poetry readings and activities articulated with CAM’s current exhibitions and “Lightscapes: Reenvisioning the Shanshuihua, featuring KAY ULUNDAY BARRETT, MURIEL LEUNG, NICK DONG, ADDIE TSAI, HENRY LIEN and moderated by CB Lee. Followed by a panel discussion and networking reception, this multimedia event celebrates art and creativity at the intersection of Asian American identity and the LGBTQ+ community.

 

 

THE IMPACT

Community events like these are pivotal towards our understanding of ourselves and others, and offer a chance for people within the community to meet others, to validate their existence and to see that they are not alone in their experience. This celebration inspires and invigorates the culture of arts and creativity and also provides a way for people to connect and discover new creators and works to support. 

 

GOALS

 

EVENT LAUNCH

Organizing events like this requires investment in administrative organizing, donations to nonprofit venues, managing volunteers, and also paying for necessary expenses such as audio and visual equipment rentals, staging, lighting, parking, and providing honorariums for speakers. As working artists and creators, it is important to compensate people for their valuable time and to value their contributions.

 

DONATION TO CAUSES WE BELIEVE IN

Our goal is to raise enough funds to donate to our venue, the Chinese American Museum, a 501C nonprofit organization, and also three nonprofits we believe strongly in: Lambda Literary, CAPE, and the Trevor Project.

 

AN ANNUAL CELEBRATION AND MORE 

We also want to continue to curate this event annually, and expand and grow as a point of connection for our community, and be able to sponsor short films and more events like these.

 

HOW YOU CAN HELP

We have a number of ways you can support this event, regardless if you wish to attend the September 27, 2019 event in Los Angeles. We are collaborating with The Gaysian Project where a portion of the proceeds from their classic Thank U For Seeing Us Shirt will benefit the event and our causes in addition to the perks offered through this IndieGoGo.

Your support and donation would mean so much to creating this community event. We have a number of exclusive perks for IndieGoGo backers, including a supersoft "Celebrate Who You Are" tee, a tote bag,  1" diameter buttons, signed books, and gift packages. Click on the right on each perk for more details. Any proceeds donated above our project goal will be donated to Lambda Literary, the Chinese American Museum, CAPE, and The Trevor Project.

 

ABOUT LAMBDA LITERARY & LAMBDA LITFEST

Lambda Literary nurtures and advocates for LGBTQ writers, elevating the impact of their words to create community, preserve our legacies, and affirm the value of our stories and our lives.
The second annual Lambda LitFest Los Angeles is a celebration of contemporary voices honoring and expanding on the rich, diverse tradition of LGBTQ writers and readers in the Southland. 

 

ABOUT THE CHINESE AMERICAN MUSEUM

The Chinese American Museum is a museum located in Downtown Los Angeles as a part of the El Pueblo de Los Angeles Historic Monument. It is dedicated to the history and experience of Chinese Americans in the state of California, the first such museum in Southern California.

 

ABOUT THE GAYSIAN PROJECT

Maya Reddy, the founder of the Gaysian Project, says, "The Queer Asian community exists but is not visible. We are not visible in Western Media or many other ordinary spaces, and, in my experience as a Queer Indian woman, it has made it difficult to find a sense of belonging or community.  When we are not seen, we are not known. That sense of loneliness is overpowering. Rarely are all Asian ethnicities recognized. And just as rarely are all identities of queerness celebrated, especially within Asian representation." This project was born out of a somewhat selfish desire to find a community and place of belonging as a Queer Asian. The Gaysian Project’s home website will serve as a hub for resources for the Queer and Asian communities. 

 

ABOUT CAPE

Since 1991, The Coalition of Asian Pacifics in Entertainment has championed diversity by educating, connecting, and empowering Asian American and Pacific Islander artists and leaders in entertainment and media. 

 

ABOUT THE TREVOR PROJECT

The Trevor Project is an American non-profit organization founded in 1998 focused on suicide prevention efforts among lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and questioning youth. Through a toll-free telephone number, it operates The Trevor Lifeline, a confidential service that offers trained counselors.

 

ABOUT THE 2019 GUESTS

 

KAY ULANDAY BARRETT

 

Kay Ulanday Barrett aka @brownroundboi is a poet, performer, and cultural strategist. K. has featured at The Lincoln Center, Symphony Space, Princeton University, Tucson Poetry Festival, NY Poetry Festival, The Poetry Project, The Dodge Poetry Foundation, The Hemispheric Institute, & Brooklyn Museum to name a few. They are a 2x Pushcart Prize nominee and received fellowships from Lambda Literary Review, VONA/Voices, The Home School, Pink Door, and Macondo. They’ve previously served as Guest Faculty for The Poetry Foundation & Crescendo Literary, as well as Guest Editor for Nat.Brut. Their contributions are found in Academy of American Poets, The New York Times, Asian American Literary Review, PBS News Hour, Poets House, F(r)iction, VIDA Review, NYLON, The Huffington Post, Them., & Bitch Magazine. Their first book, When The Chant Comes was published by Topside Press in 2016. Their second collection More Than Organs, will be published by Sibling Rivalry Press, Spring 2020. 

 

HENRY LIEN

 

 

Henry Lien was born in Taiwan, and currently lives in Hollywood. He is a 2012 graduate of Clarion West. He is the author of the award-winning and critically-acclaimed Peasprout Chen middle grade fantasy series, on which he was mentored by George R.R. Martin, Chuck Palahniuk, and Kelly Link at Clarion West. His work has received starred reviews in Publishers Weekly, Kirkus Reviews, and Booklist and acclaim in the New York Times, and been a finalist for three Nebula awards. Publishers Weekly, Logo Network, and Book Riot also included the Peasprout Chen books in their lists of top LGBTQ books. Henry has worked as an attorney, fine art dealer, and college instructor. Hobbies include writing and performing campy science fiction/fantasy anthems, and losing Nebula awards.

 

ADDIE TSAI

Addie Tsai teaches courses in literature, creative writing, dance, and humanities at Houston Community College. She collaborated with Dominic Walsh Dance Theater on Victor Frankenstein and Camille Claudel, among others. Addie holds an MFA from Warren Wilson College and a PhD in Dance from Texas Woman’s University. Her writing has been published in Banango Street, The Offing, The Collagist, The Feminist Wire, Nat. Brut., and elsewhere. Her queer Asian young adult novel, Dear Twin, is forthcoming from Metonymy Press in November 2019. She is the Nonfiction Editor at The Grief Diaries, Senior Associate Editor in Poetry at The Flexible Persona, Assistant Fiction Editor at Anomaly, and Senior Editor of Culture and Interviews at Raising Mothers. Addie Tsai’s photo credits: Cut Loose Salon

 

NICK DONG

 

Nick Dong 董承濂 is a conceptual metalsmith, mixed-media sculptor, and socio-commodity engineer who ignites experiential moments. He was born in 1973 in Taipei, Taiwan and lives and works in Oakland, California. After completing his BFA at Tunghai University in Taiwan, Dong obtained his MFA at the University of Oregon. In 2012 he exhibited a site-specific installation at the Renwick Gallery of the Smithsonian American Art Museum, and he presented immersive installations at the San Jose Institute of Contemporary Art in 2016. As the founder of studioDONG, he leads a team to produce experiential mixed-media sculptures, objects, and installations that combine an advanced knowledge of materials and techniques with the goal of engaging an audience’s experience beyond the optical.   

 

CB LEE

CB Lee is a bisexual Chinese-Vietnamese American writer whose novels include the Sidekick Squad series, a young adult science fiction adventure that follow queer teens who take on a corrupt government superhero agency, and also the fantasy Seven Tears At High Tide. Lee’s work has been featured in Teen Vogue, Wired Magazine, and Hypable. Not Your Sidekick was a 2017 Lambda Literary Awards Finalist in YA/Children’s Fiction and a 2017 Bisexual Book Awards Finalist in Speculative Fiction. Seven Tears at High Tide was the recipient of a Rainbow Award for Best Bisexual Fantasy Romance and also a finalist for the 2016 Bisexual Book Awards in the YA and Speculative Fiction categories.

MURIEL LEUNG

 

 

Muriel Leung is the author of Bone Confetti, winner of the 2015 Noemi Press Book Award. A Pushcart Prize nominated writer, her writing can be found in The Baffler, Cream City Review, Gulf Coast, The Collagist, Fairy Tale Review, and others. She is a recipient of fellowships to Kundiman, VONA/Voices Workshop and the Community of Writers. She is the Poetry Co-Editor of Apogee Journal and host of The Blood-Jet Writing Hour podcast with Rachelle Cruz and MT Vallarta. She is a member of Miresa Collective, a feminist speakers bureau. Currently, she is a Dornsife Fellow in Creative Writing and Literature at the University of Southern California. She is from Queens, NY. For more information about her work, please visit www.murielleung.com.
story_txt: OverviewCelebrating the Asian American LGBTQ+ Experience is an annual community event founded by author CB Lee that brings together LGBTQ+ Asian Americans for an evening of discussion, performances, and audience Q&A in historic downtown Los Angeles as part of Lambda Litfest. This year's event takes place on September 27, 2019 at the Chinese American Museum with Kay Ulunday Barrett, Nick Dong, Addie Tsai, Henry Lien, and Muriel Leung, moderated by CB Lee, and is free to the public.WHY LGBTQ+ ASIAN AMERICAN EVENTS?Hello! I’m CB Lee, author of the SIDEKICK SQUAD series. As a queer Chinese-Vietnamese American, growing up, I felt pretty isolated and unsure of who I was, as part of the LGBTQ+ community and growing up as part of multiple cultures. Maya Reddy states in the Mission Statement of the Gaysian Project, “When we are not seen, we are not known. That sense of loneliness is overpowering. Rarely are all Asian ethnicities recognized. And just as rarely are all identities of queerness celebrated, especially within Asian American representation.”  Representation is just a small part of this event—it’s about creating and fostering community. As a writer, I seek to tell stories that not only entertain but also inspire others and show inclusive characters who reflect the world we live in. In 2017, I curated the first iteration of this event in partnership with the Chinese American Museum, and was overwhelmed by the amount of amazing people who turned up for what I thought would be a modest reading and panel. Instead, the CAM courtyard overflowed with community and people who came together to see our performers, explore the exhibits and participate in a lively discussion. This year, with your support, I’m hoping to create a unique and enriching experience for the community, working with the Chinese American Museum and the Gaysian Project to encourage people to explore the amazing exhibits at the museum and also participate in an evening of discussion.CELEBRASIANQ seeks to bring together Asian Americans in the LGBTQ+ community with events that celebrate who they are in a space that inspires creativity, conversation and celebration.   2019: CELEBRATING THE ASIAN AMERICAN LGBTQ+ EXPERIENCE CELEBRATING THE ASIAN AMERICAN LGBTQ+ EXPERIENCE brings together Asian American artists, writers, and creative industry professionals in the LGBTQ+ community in historic downtown Los Angeles at the Chinese American Museum for Lambda Literary’s LitFest 2019 for an evening of community and celebrating art and creativity. CAM’s current exhibition, “Lightscapes: Reenvisioning the Shanshuihua,” reimagines the philosophies of Chinese landscape paintings with new media and immersive light-based installations. The masters of Chinese landscape art would often retreat to nature to examine the themes of harmony and balance in the cosmos, as well as find sanctuary in nature. For the LGBTQ+ community, finding balance and safety to express ourselves is one of the challenges of everyday life. Where do we go as a community to retreat and how do we find balance in our lives?Lambda Literary and CAM invite you to join us for an evening of special performances, poetry readings and activities articulated with CAM’s current exhibitions and “Lightscapes: Reenvisioning the Shanshuihua, featuring KAY ULUNDAY BARRETT, MURIEL LEUNG, NICK DONG, ADDIE TSAI, HENRY LIEN and moderated by CB Lee. Followed by a panel discussion and networking reception, this multimedia event celebrates art and creativity at the intersection of Asian American identity and the LGBTQ+ community.  THE IMPACTCommunity events like these are pivotal towards our understanding of ourselves and others, and offer a chance for people within the community to meet others, to validate their existence and to see that they are not alone in their experience. This celebration inspires and invigorates the culture of arts and creativity and also provides a way for people to connect and discover new creators and works to support.  GOALS EVENT LAUNCHOrganizing events like this requires investment in administrative organizing, donations to nonprofit venues, managing volunteers, and also paying for necessary expenses such as audio and visual equipment rentals, staging, lighting, parking, and providing honorariums for speakers. As working artists and creators, it is important to compensate people for their valuable time and to value their contributions. DONATION TO CAUSES WE BELIEVE INOur goal is to raise enough funds to donate to our venue, the Chinese American Museum, a 501C nonprofit organization, and also three nonprofits we believe strongly in: Lambda Literary, CAPE, and the Trevor Project. AN ANNUAL CELEBRATION AND MORE We also want to continue to curate this event annually, and expand and grow as a point of connection for our community, and be able to sponsor short films and more events like these. HOW YOU CAN HELPWe have a number of ways you can support this event, regardless if you wish to attend the September 27, 2019 event in Los Angeles. We are collaborating with The Gaysian Project where a portion of the proceeds from their classic Thank U For Seeing Us Shirt will benefit the event and our causes in addition to the perks offered through this IndieGoGo.Your support and donation would mean so much to creating this community event. We have a number of exclusive perks for IndieGoGo backers, including a supersoft "Celebrate Who You Are" tee, a tote bag,  1" diameter buttons, signed books, and gift packages. Click on the right on each perk for more details. Any proceeds donated above our project goal will be donated to Lambda Literary, the Chinese American Museum, CAPE, and The Trevor Project. ABOUT LAMBDA LITERARY & LAMBDA LITFESTLambda Literary nurtures and advocates for LGBTQ writers, elevating the impact of their words to create community, preserve our legacies, and affirm the value of our stories and our lives.The second annual Lambda LitFest Los Angeles is a celebration of contemporary voices honoring and expanding on the rich, diverse tradition of LGBTQ writers and readers in the Southland.  ABOUT THE CHINESE AMERICAN MUSEUMThe Chinese American Museum is a museum located in Downtown Los Angeles as a part of the El Pueblo de Los Angeles Historic Monument. It is dedicated to the history and experience of Chinese Americans in the state of California, the first such museum in Southern California. ABOUT THE GAYSIAN PROJECTMaya Reddy, the founder of the Gaysian Project, says, "The Queer Asian community exists but is not visible. We are not visible in Western Media or many other ordinary spaces, and, in my experience as a Queer Indian woman, it has made it difficult to find a sense of belonging or community.  When we are not seen, we are not known. That sense of loneliness is overpowering. Rarely are all Asian ethnicities recognized. And just as rarely are all identities of queerness celebrated, especially within Asian representation." This project was born out of a somewhat selfish desire to find a community and place of belonging as a Queer Asian. The Gaysian Project’s home website will serve as a hub for resources for the Queer and Asian communities.  ABOUT CAPESince 1991, The Coalition of Asian Pacifics in Entertainment has championed diversity by educating, connecting, and empowering Asian American and Pacific Islander artists and leaders in entertainment and media.  ABOUT THE TREVOR PROJECTThe Trevor Project is an American non-profit organization founded in 1998 focused on suicide prevention efforts among lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and questioning youth. story:
Infringement

The Infringement Festival is a vital part of Buffalo's art culture, and a summer tradition that's been going strong for 15 years. We have acts that cover theater, music, art, dance, spoken word, film, and even some artists that defy genre categorizations altogether.  All proceeds---cover charges, pass-the-hat donations---go directly to the artists, with the bare minimum set aside to cover technical expenses. We need your financial help to produce the festival program and cover technical expenses.

Can you support us in this endeavor? You'll be able to say that you directly support the arts in Buffalo.

What We Need & What You Get

We publish a large insert in the Public, one of the local "alternative" weeklies, as well as ads in other publications. We also rent PA and stage gear for a limited number of venues.

We still need about $2000, on top of what we've raised through fundraiser concerts.

We offer festival t-shirts and stickers/decals as rewards for funding us.

Every little bit counts. We've never fallen short, and with your help, 2018 will be no different.

Impact

We are the largest (but not the only) festival of our kind. Although the original Infringement Festival was started and is still run in Montreal, QC by one of the original founders, Buffalo's festival is the only one that has expanded to 11 days and 400+ artists.

Your donation supports artists. It allows for works to be presented both in interesting, unique spaces and by artists who do not normally get a lot of exposure. We cover a range of aesthetics, experience-levels, and we allow artists to get out of their comfort zones and present original, new, and challenging work.

Your donation also supports audiences. Without the people who come out to shows, this festival would not continue to exist.

Risks & Challenges

There is always the risk of a budgetary shortfall, or that some venue will suddenly close. Our organizer committee is our biggest strength. Collectively, we have 100+ years of experience making this thing a reality. We are also constantly bringing in new people to help us figure out how to make things happen.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that you may not be able to help us financially. Here's how you can help us:

Share our campaign with your networks.

Volunteer to help at the festival or in the weeks leading up to it. We'll find something for you to do.

Submit a performance/screening/etc. proposal (next year).

Come out and support us. Attend!

We cannot do this without you! Thank you so very much.

story:
My name is Matt Gilbert. I'm Gwich'in Athabascan. I grew  up in Arctic Village, Alaska, but I travelled arounda  lot in the states and overseas. I returned home and finished my Masters Degree in Rural Development with my thesis on oral history translations of ancient Gwich'in stories. The work lead to cultural preservation work that lasted 7 years.

About 4 years ago, I worked with an Elder Kias who was 90 years-old, because no one had ever spoken to him. Fearing all his knowledge would be lost, I walked over to his house and worked with him on commenting on an existing placename map. Little did I know, this would lead to 4 years of hard work mapping traditional placenames and trails and adding to the placename data that had already been done by Richard Caulfield in 1980. 

I hired dozens of Gwich'in Elders and Hunters in almost all the Gwich'in villages to comment on work that had already been done in Gwich'in Placename mapping and also adding new commentary to the existing ones. 

The work is now culminating in a giant database system that the Council of Athabascan Tribal Governments and the University of Alaska Fairbanks have partnered to create. This giant database will include all Gwich'in Placename and trails. I will add my materials to it too, and then it will turn into a Web Portal, which will be accessible to any Gwich'in person with a computer. 

I need $500.00, $400 of it will go toward paying the fees of Barret Ristroph, so she can help me complete my Gwich'in maps by September 15, because the company I am contracted with gave me the date to complete the work. The rest will be fees associated with using IndieGoGo and miscellaneous expenses related to the project. 

Barrett Ristroph is a PhD Student at the University of Alaska Fairbanks, but also has a law degree. She will be assisting me with two things: 

1. She will bring together hand-drawn notes and maps from various elders and organizing them according to place. 

2. She will draft notes or transcripts associated with a place and enter them into Google Earth. 

I will hire her for 4 hours, so she will finish the Arctic Village Placenames and trails. The two Elders left to do in Arctic Village is Gideon and Allen, their information and placename information is vast, so Barrett will organize it and enter the information into Google Earth or a customized database, while I finish Venetie's vast information. 

We hope to finish by September 15. 

The perks of the Gwich'in Postcards is something that was required by IndieGoGo, but I can make those for you. 

If I don't reach my goal, the funds will to get as many hours as I can out of my assistant to finish the project. 

I have been completing these projects like this for 4 years. I will get it done. 

By donating, you will be apart of an historical event. 

Thank you very much (Mahsi cho)
