story:
Let's Get The Spot HOT!

The Spot will be a space that is inclusive to the creative community; whether that be music, workshops, forums, business meetings, etc. 

We strive to help those creatives to find their space through our core values. We give space for creatives in all aspects of life, to perfect their craft, to entertain audiences with art, to cultivate inspiration and influence,  and to teach skills that will benefit others for a lifetime.

We are counting on the community to help us get there! This will be a place for the people by the people!


“Once you find it, you’re always welcome back.”

 

What We Need & What You Get

What You Get

By supporting this project you are showing that you care about your local art community. You are letting us know that you want a place that you can make your own. We are committed to making that happen.

By choosing any perk you get access to all of our fundraiser shows before we open in April. There’s also shirts, stickers, mugs and free shows for all of our higher-level donors.

The free shows will be spread out through our first fiscal year of business (ends in 2021). By buying one of our perks you are guaranteeing your spot in The Spot’s biggest and best shows. The spots are limited though so make sure you get yours today!

What We Need

We have 4 major areas of need:

 

Bills: These are the most important and will be paid first. These are the same bills everyone has: electric, water, etc. They are due prior to us opening so we need to raise those funds in order to get the building ready to go.

Business Costs: These are things like insurance payments and legal costs. These are needed to be able to legally open the doors to the community.

Building Costs: Building costs are our biggest cost for a reason. There’s a lot of work to be done in the building before it’s ready to go in April. This money goes to things like curtains, lighting, signs, and bathrooms.

Entertainment Improvements: Last but not least we have the cost of our entertainment features. Think of things like sound systems, screens, projectors, and new live instruments. Once we have everything running we want to make sure we have everything we need to make the place as fun as possible. That’s what this money goes towards.

Our Impact

Our goal is to not only empower and inspire the block we are located on but to expand that mission to the entire creative community in the QC. 

There are many talented local artists in a multitude of genres that want to be heard. Our mission is to serve that community by providing a space for them to be able to express themselves creatively. 

We want to do all of this while providing an opportunity for them to monetize their art.

Our Risks & Challenges

Our main challenge has been getting the ball rolling with start-up money. We desire to give the place a makeover, in order to make the space more comfortable for everyone. 

What are we doing about it?

This fundraiser is the start but we will be doing much more to raise funds. We will also sell merch and do fundraising shows all the way up until we open

Another challenge we will face is reaching the community to get the word out!

What are we doing about it?

We are going to be blasting the good news all over the QC! Anyone that loves live music and art should know that The Spot is a place they can come to support artistry of all kinds!

Other Ways You Can Help

We know not everyone who wants to help can so here are a few things you can do to help that cost no money at all!

Share this campaign on all of your socials

Speak to the members of your community about this project

Send us artists suggestions of who’d you like to see perform at our venue

Send us suggestions on the improvements you’d like to see at The Spot

Entertainment Improvements: Last but not least we have the cost of our entertainment features. Think of things like sound systems, screens, projectors, and new live instruments. Once we have everything running we want to make sure we have everything we need to make the place as fun as possible. That’s what this money goes towards.
Our Impact
Our goal is to not only empower and inspire the block we are located on but to expand that mission to the entire creative community in the QC. 
There are many talented local artists in a multitude of genres that want to be heard. Our mission is to serve that community by providing a space for them to be able to express themselves creatively. 
We want to do all of this while providing an opportunity for them to monetize their art.
Our Risks & Challenges
Our main challenge has been getting the ball rolling with start-up money. We desire to give the place a makeover, in order to make the space more comfortable for everyone. 
What are we doing about it?
This fundraiser is the start but we will be doing much more to raise funds. We will also sell merch and do fundraising shows all the way up until we open
Another challenge we will face is reaching the community to get the word out!
What are we doing about it?
We are going to be blasting the good news all over the QC! Anyone that loves live music and art should know that The Spot is a place they can come to support artistry of all kinds!
Other Ways You Can Help
We know not everyone who wants to help can so here are a few things you can do to help that cost no money at all!
Share this campaign on all of your socials
Speak to the members of your community about this project
Send us artists suggestions of who’d you like to see perform at our venue
Send us suggestions on the improvements you’d like to see at The Spot

story:
We were there for 8 years, our previous space in Yau Ma Tei.

We are...

a group of friends, many of whom first encountered each other in the year-long occupation of the basement of HSBC bank headquarters in 2011, who have come together out of a combination of contingency and necessity. Whether we found one another in guerilla gig moshpits on the streets, transporting subwoofers to contraband parties in abandoned bus depots or warehouse roofs, huddled close in ramshackle forts and treehouses defending farmland in the Northeast territories, sleeping on couches beneath flyovers staring at the stars with homeless friends facing eviction, encamped in tents on the water, singing karaoke with dockworkers on strike, or- as it turned out in the end- running a tiny makeshift al fresco vegan kitchen-cum-infoshop in a cul-de-sac cut off from the rest of the city, we are, down to the last of us, spawn of an unremittingly hostile environment, a metropolis that deems every form of living, every inch of inhabited territory that runs contrary to the mandates of the market to be a threat.

 

In Hong Kong...

The sensational events of 2019 appeared to have drawn international attention to the ongoing catastrophe that is our city, but the narrative that surrounded the warfare was often couched in terms that are in danger of obscuring the stakes that were in play. In order to solicit these sympathies and maintain them in the face of rapidly escalating events elsewhere, partisans in Hong Kong were compelled to style themselves as freedom fighters manning the crumbling ramparts of the free world, heralds sounding the siren of the approaching red deluge.

 In the aftermath of the tumult, a solidarity economy (the so-called ‘yellow economic circle’) has formed among partisans to render services and assistance among one another, withdrawing resources, support and labour away from businesses that are on the side of the state and its footsoldiers. 

This is, without question, an endeavor that is as worthwhile as it is necessary, but if we have, until this point, been hesitant to declare ourselves as being card-carrying members of the yellow economic circle, it is certainly not because we are situated on the opposite side of the ideological spectrum. Rather, it is because, for one thing, we do not define ourselves simply through economic terms as a food and beverage establishment (though of course we need to find the means to sustain the space and our own livelihoods), and for another, any ‘freedom’ that we aspire towards is not that of national sovereignty or political ‘independence’, but the power to- as the Situationists declared- produce ourselves and our own capacities, rather than the things that enslave us and separate us from our potentiality. It is this very power, materialized in the collective skills, knowledges and practices that we are able to share and develop among one another, that we have always wanted to build, multiply and circulate. This is the only means by which we can begin to counter the despoliation, expropriation and impoverishment to which we have been condemned, by seizing and appropriating the wealth that surrounds us and putting it to a different use, that of building the bases for a different life, and the means to defend it.


Dishes around the world, vegetarian version


Our previous infoshop. In the coming new space, there'll be vegetarian food, infoshop, comics corner, music, screening and block-printing studio.

A space needed...

For this circulation and this sharing to take place, however, it is obvious that we require actual sites and places to meet and conspire, territories that we can claim and consolidate as our own, where we can speak, think and live among friends, where those in need can find shelter, refuge, care and substantive sustenance, physical and spiritual. We are in dire need of maps that indicate territories, provisional or permanent, that we have seized, that we are cultivating and that we must protect. A cartography that tells you where you need to go if you want to learn how to code or farm, if you want to pick up kendo, kickboxing or parkour, if you are interested in the rudiments of acupuncture or yogic breathing, if you are in search of contraband texts on occult subjects and a means to reproduce them for distribution among all of your friends. It is our hope that we can make a modest but enduring contribution to the building of such a place.

 

From So Boring to Black Window

In a previous incarnation, we were once known as the So Boring kitchen, a ramshackle hole in the wall vegan ‘restaurant’ operating on the street. On any given night, you could show up and find yourself faced with a menu packed with dishes that you had never heard of, pairing, perhaps, a Cantonese soup with a West African stew and Thai pudding for dessert. For lack of waiting staff, you would have to find a place on the curb among a throng of misfits, place an order in a cramped, noisy hole-in-the-wall kitchen and patiently await the arrival of food that could very possibly be sold out by the time the cooks begin preparing your portion. 

 

Despite all of this, So Boring became an infamous destination for the adventurous, the destitute, and of course those who wanted a nutritious meal and company without having much money to pay for it. So infamous, in fact, that the district councillor became as ardent to snuff out this den of vagrants as he did all the impromptu homeless shacks that have been wiped out in the area over the years. Tired of the constant raids by government departments invoked by the councillor and realizing that our tiny space had perhaps exhausted its potential, we decided to close the space and the street that we had inhabited  with friends near and far for the better part of 6 years. Too much of our time and energy ,time that could have been devoted to endeavors that were far more worthwhile, was occupied in our efforts to evade and defy the letter of the law, dodging punishment for not being a properly licensed and registered restaurant. This evasion was not motivated by a simple taste for criminality, we simply did not regard ourselves as being a restaurant, and we certainly didn’t treat the street as the dining room for a food and beverage establishment. The space that housed our kitchen just happened to serve food, but serving food was simply one among many things that we did, though it eventually became the case that everything else that we did was eclipsed by the kitchen, its notoriety and the demands that it placed upon those of us who had to keep it running through times of scarcity and need. Also, there was the fact that people who came to the kitchen had no real idea about the people behind it, what exactly their principles were beyond the odd political pronouncement every now and then on our social media, what other things they were engaged in. As a consequence, it was easy to mistake those of us in the kitchen as being ‘chefs’ in the business of cooking for clientele.

 

It is clear, then, that we need a considerably bigger space, for one thing, and that we need to license and register it properly, for another, so that we don’t waste inordinate amounts of time devising strategies to outsmart the authorities. All of this attention and concern will instead go into coordinating screenings, curating our library, organizing discussions and workshops, as well as creating a solid and sustainable basis to support ourselves and, hopefully, other folks that require our support or assistance (for example, So Boring once ran collaborative nights with the Bethune House, which provides shelter for domestic migrant workers in need, and which was facing closure because of the withdrawal of funding). Because we have resolved to maintain appearances and adopt the guise, superficially at least, of a ‘legit’ restaurant, this will create costs and headaches that we have never known before. This is also why, despite all of our own efforts to save money ourselves, we are asking for your kind and deeply appreciated assistance to build the foundations of our space, and to help us establish a reserve fund so that we can weather the unpredictability of the post-pandemic climate and create a foundation upon which we can continue to build for the next few years.


Charity dinner for Bethune House, a migrant domestic workers' shelter in Hong Kong.


Screening on the street.


Street market held in the neighborhood.


Zines and independent music albums.


Farewell Yau Ma Tei. Looking forward to see you all again.

Budget plan

Projected opening date：June-July, 2021

Total expenditure required：$1047,978

Amount that we currently have on hand：$523,541.9

 

Money that we need to raise: Approximately $500,000
($400,000 will be raise on a local fund raising platform)

Any assistance, however small, is deeply appreciated!!

＝＝＝＝＝＝＝＝＝＝ 

 

Detailed breakdown：

 

Total expenditure required：$1047,978

 

Rent deposit    $163,000
Renovation and materials    $500,000Licenses for the bar and restaurant    $23,940

Operating costs for the first month    $161,038

Reserve/emergency fund    $200,000

Remaining funds from our last fundraising drive in 2017    $50,366.9

Savings pooled together from members of the collective        $475,000

Cash that we currently have on hand：($50,366.9+ $475,000=)  $523,541.9

Money that we require (Total expenditure- Money we already have)：$995,200 - 523,541.9 = $524,436.1

-----

*Note 1： Our first fundraising drive was held in 2017 as a consequence of our landlord raising the rent and forcing us to move. The breakdown of that fundraiser is as follows:

 

Money raised          73,067

 

Installation of electrical outlets      3,579.1
Kitchen installation and materials      1,190
Installation of pipes     3,000
Installation of exhaust fans     2,400
Construction of kitchen tabletops and materials     3,200
Carpentry and materials          1,800
Installation of front gate          500
Water filtration device    1,680
Replacement of kitchenware and other miscellaneous costs     2,031
Promotional materials     1,440
Administrative banking costs     1,400
Transportation and other related costs        480

Total remaining sum        50,366.9

 

More About Us

Facebook(@openblackwindow)：https://bit.ly/3t6kXel

Instagram (@blackwindow___)：https://bit.ly/37u3ZP1

Hong Kong: Anarchists in the Resistance to the Extradition Bill  https://bit.ly/3vxcxOH

Three Months of Insurrection: An Anarchist Collective in Hong Kong Appraises the Achievements and Limits of the Revolt  https://bit.ly/3nHtPWD

story:
Support Catalonia

This is a short pitch.

I want to support Catalan independence. I hope that you do to. I propose to put 1,000 Catalan flags on the streets of Scotland.

We've done this before. We know how to do it, and we're already set up to do it.

We'll get the flags made in China (because everything is these days), fly them in, and then distribute them to Yes groups by the end of November. Donating £20 or more gets you a flag as a perk.

1,000 flags at £1.50 each = £1,500

£ 650 air freight

VAT and Import Duty £559

Total £2,709 (plus 10% crowdfunding/payment fees and rounding brings us to £3,000).

Should we go over target, we'll also try to get more Yes Saltires as the Yes groups are still crying out for these. As before, the Yes groups will be able to sell the flags to raise funds for their own local campaigns.

 

What You Get

Donate £20 or more and we'll send you a Catalan flag as soon as they arrive. If you're a Yes group, register with the National Yes Registry and you'll receive a pack of flags to distribute at your discretion.

Let's show our support for Catalonia on Scotland's streets.

story:
Short Summary

Vernacular Art-space Laboratory Foundation (VAL Foundation) is a non-profit artist-led initiative, founded in 2006 in Lagos, Nigeria, as an alternative art space where artists cohabit to exchange ideas and co-create works with uncommon flair. Exploring the idea of non-space, our activities take place in alternative and abandoned spaces within the Iwaya/Makoko community area.

Our main focus is to provide platform for collaborative practice between artist-networks from Nigeria, West Africa, and other countries, with interdisciplinary art project as the central guiding principle. Our mission is to create an atmosphere where contemporary visual art forms can be actualized and presented through community engagement and civic participation. Through our projects, we collaborate with local and international artist-networks to develop artistic interventions that are enriching, entertaining and educating in our community.

Target Groups

For us, it is essential to engage with youth in Iwaya community from all background and gender. We will open the youth’s participation through many different roles and forms of active engagement. Among others are volunteer to assist the work team and participating artists, writers and editorial team for the Community Newsletter, participants for the artist-led workshops, logistics, production and community activities like sport show. This opportunity will be performed through an open call for each different role and will be communicated through website, social media, and print poster.

I C A F Lagos 2018 Program Activities:

A multi-day festival

One-month artist-in-residence

Community activities: sport show, artist-led workshops for youth, outdoor video art & film screening, poetry/spoken-words performance

What We Need For I C A F Lagos 2018

USD 14,275

 

What You Get for Supporting I C A F Lagos 2018

We invite to sponsor concerts, symposium, artist talks, artist-led workshop for youth of Iwaya/Makoko community in Lagos. We have some gifts that will interest you, please check the perks for the items. 

Iwaya Community Art Festival (I C A F Lagos)

Objectives

Inhabit in a coastal community, which largely dominated by low-income earners, I C A F Lagos aim is to provide access for underprivileged people in the community to experience art and to develop space for intercultural dialogue on socio-political issues that shapes our daily lives. Through our program activities, we further aim:

to enhance community-driven initiatives to celebrate their sense of place

to strengthen the role of youth in the community to voice their perspectives about their ideal living space

to provide platforms for both artistic and cultural exchange

 

Communal Re-Imagination

(students of Communal Re-Imagination, an alternative art school project funded by Prince Claus Fund, participating in a performance by Yusuf Durodola)

After two years of focusing on issues that are more transnational in scope, the Artistic Director of Iwaya Community Art Festival — I C A F Lagos, has decided to address a domestic issue from an inclusive perspective. Communal Re-Imagination as the theme of the third edition of I C A F Lagos is adapted from the year-long alternative community art school project by the Vernacular Art-space Laboratory, in Iwaya Community.

Iwaya as a community is not static, it has changed over time. Lagos as an urban space has also evolved with time both in aesthetics and population; the latter explains the intensive quest for survival and also why many people do not smile any more in public spaces. Similar to some big cities around the world, depression has become a sickness that the state now identifies as one of  the periodic causes of deaths on its Lagoon.

I C A F Lagos 2018 is immersed in the interconnectedness of “villages” — (communities) within Lagos City to ignite the fundamentality of its public space. Lagos as a city is made up of several communities (villages) that have different socio-cultural facilities distributed on its Island and Mainland. The economic hub of the city was by default built on the Island owing to its waterways that are linked to the Atlantic Ocean and this limits functional communal spaces on the mainland where Iwaya, as a village, is a suburb of the city.

Static communities are unliveable; they confine people to their homes and repress their minds and souls. To debunk this stagnation that befalls our villages within urban spaces, urbanism has to be employed to regenerate spaces for a new utopia. Communal Re-Imagination seeks creative confluence through open-source with architects, anthropologists, socio-cultural historians and artists to restructure our static villages that are rustic in mood in order to re-dynamise their architectural presence and relevance. Through open source and right resources, together, villages can be rebuilt and the mood and culture of the villagers will be reactivated.

With the theme of I C A F Lagos 2018, the festival proposes a collaboration between people living within the community who understand both the socio-cultural notion and anthropological nuances of Iwaya and visual narratives from the participating artists. This collaboration intends to redesign the architectural fabric through a merger of native ideas and contemporary artistic practices in the creation of functional alternative spaces and installation of objects culminating in the regeneration of the community.

Furthermore, the political class and community leaders are requested to be the moderators in this urbanism discourse on space re-appropriation for popular culture narrative as an alternative platform to annexing the immense but uncultivated energy of the youth that permeates Iwaya Community. All players will harmoniously animate Iwaya as a village with suggestions and narratives through this dialogue.

 

Project Plan and Timeframe

The third and fourth edition of ICAF Lagos in 2018 and 2019 respectively will focus on the regeneration of the community through partnership with local residents who are experts of daily live, community-based organizations, interdisciplinary artists and creative practitioners from Nigeria and West Africa countries, and importantly, youth in Iwaya community. To further explore various forms of social practices within the contemporary art field, we are intended to focus on art practices that are actively engaging with diverse social, cultural, architectural and historical context. 

 

#1 One-month Artist-in-Residence Program

Timeframe: 10th of November – 10th of December 2018.

Participating artists: Suraia Abud (Uruguay/Lebanon), Segun Adefila (Nigeria), Kris Russo (USA), Raffaele Fotunati (Italy), Yusuf Durodola (Nigeria)

Location: Iwaya Community.

 

Following the success of the first AiR program that was introduced during I C A F Lagos 2017, we continue the platform by bringing five artists that was selected through an open call. During a one-month residency period, each artist will live with one family as their host. The artworks and/or artistic projects that they created during the residency period will be exhibited during the festival.

 

#2 Art Talks

Timeframe: 2nd – 9th of December, 2018.

Participating artists: I C A F Lagos 2018 AiR programme participants

Location: VAL-Workstation, Abete Playing Ground, Pedro Village, Iwaya Market.

 

In this program activity, curators and artists will be engaged in conversations and discourses around curatorial practices and artistic practices in the visual cultural landscape, locally and internationally. Each of the talks will be streamed live on our social media platforms like Instagram, Facebook and Google+.

 

#3 Artist-led Workshop

Timeframe: 3rd – 4th of December, 2018.

Participating artists: To announced soon.

Workshop participants: youth in Iwaya community and environ.

Location: VAL-Workstation and other site-specific place.

 

To encourage public engagement with art, artists, and ideas, we invite interdisciplinary artists to conduct a workshop that will involve youth in Iwaya community as the participants. The type of workshop may vary based on the artists’ practice and interest. From skill sharing to discursive, the sky’s the limit.

 

#4 Community Activities:

Football match

Timeframe: 5th – 30th of November, 2018 and 3rd of December, 2018.

Participants: youth in Iwaya community.

Location: Abete Playing Ground, Iwaya.

 

Since 2016, we identify sport as an effective means to reach the youth in Iwaya community. The popular Abete Playing Ground in Iwaya has produced several players who have taken part in International matches and tournaments for the country and also in some of the teams that are in the Nigeria League. Some of these players are Alloysius Uzoma Agu, known as Alloy Agu, Dosu Joseph, Patrick “Tunde” Ogunsoto and the entire MFM Team amongst others. We are interested in the 5 Aside Matches that has become popular amongst the youth in Iwaya and the entire Yaba/Ebute-Metta environ. And this year, as part of the festival, the I C A F Lagos 5 Aside League will start on the 5th November and finished on 30th of November. The third place and final will be played on the Official Opening Day of I C A F Lagos 2018, which take place on 3rd of December 2018.

 

#5 Outdoor video art & film screening

Timeframe: 2nd – 9th of December, 2018.

Curator: Onyeka Nwelue (Nigeria).

Location: Abete Playing Ground and selected streets in Iwaya/Makoko/Onike area.

 

This program will screen a selection of video art and film curated by Onyeka Nwelue, a Nigerian cultural entrepreneur, filmmaker, professor and author who is best known for his novel 'The Abyssinian Boy'. Each screening will be open for public and free of charge.

 

#6 Poetry/spoken-words performance

Timeframe: 8th of December, 2018.

Curator: Rez Thapoet (Nigeria).

Location: Abete Playing Ground/Onike RoundAbout.

 

Spoken word is a performance art that is word based. It is an oral art that focuses on the aesthetics of word play such as intonation and voice inflection. It is a 'catchall' term which includes any kind of poetry recited aloud, including poetry readings, poetry slams, jazz poetry, and hip hop, and can include comedy routines and 'prose monologues'. We are collaborating with Rez Thapoet, a Nigerian poet and spoken-word artist, to curate the performance.

 

#7 Folk games

Timeframe: 2nd – 9th of December, 2018.

Participants: residents in Iwaya community from all ages.

Location: Pedro Village, Balogun Street, Pedro Street, Abete Playing Ground.

 

Through this activity, we aim to bring back folk games that are passed from generation to generation. Games such as Ludo, Draft, Chess, Ayo Opon, Eve and Sikki will be a point of convergence that allow people from different ages in the community to build meaningful interaction. Especially Eve and Sikki are known as folk games that are played by the Egun people who are the largest population at Pedro Village in Iwaya community. Each game will require a registration and winners will be awarded with prizes.


The festival will be officially open on the 3rd of December, 2018, started with a final football match to determine the first winner and then continued with a lineup of live music. After the opening day, various artistic interventions in form of site-specific installation and performances will be exhibited around Abete Playing Ground for five days until the closing event which will take place on the 9th of December, 2018. We will celebrate the closing day with public and people of Iwaya community in a live music show. All events during the festival week will be open for public and free of charge.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also contribute by sharing this campaign through your social media and emails to friends, colleagues and families:

  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Short Summary
Vernacular Art-space Laboratory Foundation (VAL Foundation) is a non-profit artist-led initiative, founded in 2006 in Lagos, Nigeria, as an alternative art space where artists cohabit to exchange ideas and co-create works with uncommon flair. Exploring the idea of non-space, our activities take place in alternative and abandoned spaces within the Iwaya/Makoko community area.
Our main focus is to provide platform for collaborative practice between artist-networks from Nigeria, West Africa, and other countries, with interdisciplinary art project as the central guiding principle. Our mission is to create an atmosphere where contemporary visual art forms can be actualized and presented through community engagement and civic participation. Through our projects, we collaborate with local and international artist-networks to develop artistic interventions that are enriching, entertaining and educating in our community.
Target Groups
For us, it is essential to engage with youth in Iwaya community from all background and gender. We will open the youth’s participation through many different roles and forms of active engagement. Among others are volunteer to assist the work team and participating artists, writers and editorial team for the Community Newsletter, participants for the artist-led workshops, logistics, production and community activities like sport show. This opportunity will be performed through an open call for each different role and will be communicated through website, social media, and print poster.
I C A F Lagos 2018 Program Activities:
A multi-day festival
One-month artist-in-residence
Community activities: sport show, artist-led workshops for youth, outdoor video art & film screening, poetry/spoken-words performance
What We Need For I C A F Lagos 2018
USD 14,275 What You Get for Supporting I C A F Lagos 2018
We invite to sponsor concerts, symposium, artist talks, artist-led workshop for youth of Iwaya/Makoko community in Lagos. We have some gifts that will interest you, please check the perks for the items. 

Iwaya Community Art Festival (I C A F Lagos)
Objectives
Inhabit in a coastal community, which largely dominated by low-income earners, I C A F Lagos aim is to provide access for underprivileged people in the community to experience art and to develop space for intercultural dialogue on socio-political issues that shapes our daily lives. Through our program activities, we further aim:
to enhance community-driven initiatives to celebrate their sense of place
to strengthen the role of youth in the community to voice their perspectives about their ideal living space
to provide platforms for both artistic and cultural exchange Communal Re-Imagination

(students of Communal Re-Imagination, an alternative art school project funded by Prince Claus Fund, participating in a performance by Yusuf Durodola)
After two years of focusing on issues that are more transnational in scope, the Artistic Director of Iwaya Community Art Festival — I C A F Lagos, has decided to address a domestic issue from an inclusive perspective. Communal Re-Imagination as the theme of the third edition of I C A F Lagos is adapted from the year-long alternative community art school project by the Vernacular Art-space Laboratory, in Iwaya Community.
Iwaya as a community is not static, it has changed over time. Lagos as an urban space has also evolved with time both in aesthetics and population; the latter explains the intensive quest for survival and also why many people do not smile any more in public spaces. Similar to some big cities around the world, depression has become a sickness that the state now identifies as one of  the periodic causes of deaths on its Lagoon.
I C A F Lagos 2018 is immersed in the interconnectedness of “villages” — (communities) within Lagos City to ignite the fundamentality of its public space. Lagos as a city is made up of several communities (villages) that have different socio-cultural facilities distributed on its Island and Mainland. The economic hub of the city was by default built on the Island owing to its waterways that are linked to the Atlantic Ocean and this limits functional communal spaces on the mainland where Iwaya, as a village, is a suburb of the city.
Static communities are unliveable; they confine people to their homes and repress their minds and souls. To debunk this stagnation that befalls our villages within urban spaces, urbanism has to be employed to regenerate spaces for a new utopia. Communal Re-Imagination seeks creative confluence through open-source with architects, anthropologists, socio-cultural historians and artists to restructure our static villages that are rustic in mood in order to re-dynamise their architectural presence and relevance. Through open source and right resources, together, villages can be rebuilt and the mood and culture of the villagers will be reactivated.
With the theme of I C A F Lagos 2018, the festival proposes a collaboration between people living within the community who understand both the socio-cultural notion and anthropological nuances of Iwaya and visual narratives from the participating artists. This collaboration intends to redesign the architectural fabric through a merger of native ideas and contemporary artistic practices in the creation of functional alternative spaces and installation of objects culminating in the regeneration of the community.
Furthermore, the political class and community leaders are requested to be the moderators in this urbanism discourse on space re-appropriation for popular culture narrative as an alternative platform to annexing the immense but uncultivated energy of the youth that permeates Iwaya Community. All players will harmoniously animate Iwaya as a village with suggestions and narratives through this dialogue.
 
Project Plan and Timeframe
The third and fourth edition of ICAF Lagos in 2018 and 2019 respectively will focus on the regeneration of the community through partnership with local residents who are experts of daily live, community-based organizations, interdisciplinary artists and creative practitioners from Nigeria and West Africa countries, and importantly, youth in Iwaya community. To further explore various forms of social practices within the contemporary art field, we are intended to focus on art practices that are actively engaging with diverse social, cultural, architectural and historical context.

Timeframe: 10th of November – 10th of December 2018.
Participating artists: Suraia Abud (Uruguay/Lebanon), Segun Adefila (Nigeria), Kris Russo (USA), Raffaele Fotunati (Italy), Yusuf Durodola (Nigeria)
Location: Iwaya Community. Following the success of the first AiR program that was introduced during I C A F Lagos 2017, we continue the platform by bringing five artists that was selected through an open call. During a one-month residency period, each artist will live with one family as their host. The artworks and/or artistic projects that they created during the residency period will be exhibited during the festival. #2 Art Talks
Timeframe: 2nd – 9th of December, 2018.
Participating artists: I C A F Lagos 2018 AiR programme participants
Location: VAL-Workstation, Abete Playing Ground, Pedro Village, Iwaya Market. In this program activity, curators and artists will be engaged in conversations and discourses around curatorial practices and artistic practices in the visual cultural landscape, locally and internationally. Each of the talks will be streamed live on our social media platforms like Instagram, Facebook and Google+. #3 Artist-led Workshop
Timeframe: 3rd – 4th of December, 2018.
Participating artists: To announced soon.
Workshop participants: youth in Iwaya community and environ.
Location: VAL-Workstation and other site-specific place. To encourage public engagement with art, artists, and ideas, we invite interdisciplinary artists to conduct a workshop that will involve youth in Iwaya community as the participants. Participants: youth in Iwaya community.
Location: Abete Playing Ground, Iwaya. Since 2016, we identify sport as an effective means to reach the youth in Iwaya community. story:
Balconville littéraire

Fierté littéraire combat isolement durant la pandémie de la COVID-19. Elle organise une deuxième rencontre littéraire virtuelle le 27 avril à 20 h en séance de visionnement Facebook.

Des auteurs/autrices et des poètes/poétesses partagent leurs mots avec vous. De leur balcon !

Joignez-vous à Pénélope McQuade, Choé Sainte-Marie, Simon Boulerice, Alain Labonté, Pascale Cormier, Daniel French et bien d'autres que nous vous annoncerons sous peu.

Billy Robinson de la librairie de Verdun vous parlera de ses coups de coeur littéraires.

Le tout est animé par l'auteur et comédien, Denis-Martin Chabot.

Cet événement est gratuit, mais nous vous invitons à faire un don à notre collecte en sociofinancement pour aider des auteurs.trices de Fierté littéraire en précarité à cause de la pandémie. Des prix seront offerts - détails à venir sous peu.

Pour revoir l'événement: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cj80KqGiBBc

Aide aux auteurs dans la précarité

Cet événement est gratuit, mais nous vous invitons à faire un don à notre collecte en sociofinancement pour aider des auteurs.trices de Fierté littéraire qui se déclarent en précarité à cause de la pandémie.

Des prix seront offerts par tirage au sort parmi les donateurs.  Entre autres, leslibraires.ca offre un certificat cadeau de 100 $ utilisable sur leur site (ou en personne après le confinement), et Fierté littéraire offre 5 exemplaires de La Fierté a une ville, le collectif de Fierté littéraire publié en 2017, parmi les personnes qui contribueront. Chaque tranche de 20 $ = 1 participation au tirage.

story:
What is OjoRojo?

OjoRojo was founded by a group of concerned photojournalists and photography teachers in 2016. Located in the center of Bogotá, OjoRojo has become an important reference point in the world of Colombian and Latin American photography: a training center where journalistic rigor is taught; the development of a personal vision is stimulated; and a space for exhibitions and gatherings with authors. At OjoRojo documentary photography is conceived as a tool that strengthens democracy and the free exchange of information, essential values for a more inclusive and peaceful society.

Why this campaign?

We have launched this Indiegogo campaign to help sustain our project and make needed improvements to our infrastructure. We appreciate any support, whether you can purchase one of the rewards we offer here or simply pass the word on to others who may be excited to support documentary photography in Colombia and Latin America in general.

Thanks to the voluntary work of our members and the participation of many photographers, educators and curators, we have maintained a robust schedule of activities for the last three years. With your help we can continue and expand upon the following activities.

 

What do we do?

Talks

To strengthen documentary practice and further a greater understanding of the social issues of our time,  we have hosted over 100 free, public projections of photographic works presented by accomplished Colombian and international photographers.

We also host free screenings of documentary films, and presentation by artists whose work incorporates photography.

One of the principal goals of OjoRojo Fábrica Visual is to promote works by women photographers and other groups traditionally underrepresented in the profession.

Exhibitions

We have maintained a cycle of exhibitions of the work of recognized and emerging photographers such as Tito Celis, Natalia Botero, Alejandra Parra,  Jorge Panchoaga, Gabriel Rojas, Viviana Peretti and others. We welcome proposals for exhibitions from the public and we emphasize work that does not require large economic investments to exhibit. The goal of these exhibitions is not only to display excellent projects that would otherwise not be accessible to Colombian audiences.

We consider OjoRojo a “Visual Factory” in the sense that,  in collaboration with our exhibitors, we constantly research local and alternative materials that enable us to exhibit work at a reasonable cost without sacrificing quality or the integrity of the work itself.

Workshops

We hold intensive workshops in documentary practice led by experienced practitioners and teachers of documentary photography.  We offer these workshops at reasonable prices and guarantee two full scholarships to each workshop. Workshops to date have focussed on documentary narrative,  street photography, the documentation of popular culture, and the role of gender in documentary practice.


Photo-shop & Photo-library

One of the primary functions of OjoRojo Fábrica Visual has been to promote the culture and industry of Colombian and Latin American photography and photobooks. We provide a platform where numerous authors offer their works for sale and where collectors or interested members of the public  can find titles otherwise unavailable in Colombia.

In addition, dozens of accomplished authors have donated their photobooks  as study material for public consultation, thus activating OjoRojo has a referential place for the development of photobook practices.

Internship program

We maintain a robust program of internships for students of the Minuto de Dios popular university.  

 

What do we need?

1. Pay rent

Our monthly costs have increased some 30% since we began the project three years ago.  

2. Lighting

Both for our exhibition space and our store we need to make modest investments in track and spot lighting to improve the viewability of the work on display.

3. Equipment

We use donated video projectors to project material on a screen during our talks.  Two of these projectors have now broken, and we need to purchase one of our own, with replacement bulbs. We also need a flat screen TV in order to broadcast the talks in our back room when we have an overflow crowd, as often happens. In addition, we have broadcast our talks via Facebook Live,  but to date we have recorded them from a cell phone. To enhance the professional quality of these broadcasts, and for other uses, we need a video camera on site.

4. Showcase

To make our photobook library more accessible to the public, we need to purchase a second-hand display cabinet with ample space to show over a hundred photobooks that have been donated to OjoRojo for public consultation.  

5. Shelving  

To accommodate our growing number of prints and products we need to expand our shelving space.  

 

What do you get for your donation,  besides the satisfaction of helping a worthy creative cause?

For this Indiegogo campaign, photographers, artists, and friends of OjoRojo have donated their books, prints and visual pieces to this effort. Please see the list of rewards to choose among photobooks, prints, and other interesting items.

story:
WHO WE ARE

FLAT is an idea by FLAT, the namesake no-profit cultural association that actively want to play a part in promoting and supporting the book and its distribution, by recognizing its important role in the diffusion and knowledge of contemporary art contents.

FLAT was founded in Turin by Chiara Caroppo, Beatrice Merz and Mario Petriccione, professionals in the contemporary art field, with the aim of creating an important platform for promoting and selling artists’ books, as well as a hub for the production and exchange of ideas.

We want to offer a space for promoting the finest international production of exhibition catalogs, monographs, essays, artists’ books, rare and out-of-print editions and magazines, while presenting a valuable show for leading publishers and small, independent presses, artists, collectors and bibliophiles from all over the world.


Maria Morganti, Leporello 30 strati #5, Venezia, 2008 (ph. Francesco Allegretto)

WHY WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT
We imagined to offer to the public an event that is accompanied by an extensive cultural program exploring the state of the international art publishing industry, alongside the practices and issues within the art-book culture.

FLAT’s CULTURAL PROGRAM features two exhibitions: the monographic show on Ettore Sottsass. Le pagine and the group exhibit Lettura per voci e silenzio, both curated by Elena Volpato. 

The exhibition on Ettore Sottsass is hosted in the rooms of Palazzo Birago, institutional seat of the Chamber of Commerce of Torino, chosen to celebrate the centennial of Sottsass’s birth and the unlimited creativity of an artist who, more than others, truly expressed himself through books and magazines, each time reinventing the shape, the meaning, and the function of the printed page. The display will offer visitors a chance to see the entire production of Sottsass’s books, periodicals and pamphlets.

The exhibit dedicated to Ettore Sottsass is complemented by the show Lettura per voci e silenzio, also curated by Elena Volpato and hosted at Palazzo Cisterna, venue of the Fair’s first edition. This exhibit is devoted to the liturgy of reading, intended both as an inner space and as a public space, an act of sharing. Some works, disseminated among the publishers’ desks in the Fair, allow visitors to listen to the voices of artists and performers reading various texts in front of the camera. They are the videos by John Baldessari, Three Feathers and Other Fairy Tales, by Martha Rosler, Martha Rosler Reads "Vogue", a work by Karl Holmqvist, I’m with you in Rockland and the choral work by Concetta Modica, In pasto al presente #3.
In a separate, secluded area, is a series of small rooms hosting about thirty works, creating an island of quietness where the space of the page and the countless shapes of the books imagined by the artists will be allowed to disclose their silence. Visitors will plunge into the perceptive infinity of Romanzo blu by Irma Blank; they will stand in front of a small block of white chalk, silent and dense, on which Paolo Icaro has inscribed the word Racconto (Tale); they will consider the endless imaginary pages and volumes adding up on Giulio Paolini’s canvases; they will read the white transparency in between words where Sabrina Mezzaqui has rewritten Karen Blixen’s The Blank Page: and finally, in the volume Universum by Maurizio Nannucci, they will contemplate an elliptic closing within itself, with two opposite bindings wrapping a book into a closed volume, into a hermetic microcosmos—the image of a “book-world”, and of a world that throughout the ages cyclically appears to men as a silent book waiting to be read. 

The fair will be sided by FLAT Public Programs, a multifaceted series of lectures, talks, conversations, readings, screenings, music and book launches. On the occasion of FLAT international artists, designers, curators, professionals and experts from the art and artist publishing world gather in Turin to present and discuss the relevance of the book as an object, medium and instrument for art, its distribution and circulation. Here the list of participants: Francesco Arena, Luca Bertolo, Irma Boom, Collective Çukurcuma (Naz Cuguoglu and Mine Kaplangi), Nicoletta Boschiero, Liliana Dematteis, Heather Ewing, Eleonora Farina, Richard Flood, Wilfried Huet, Andrea Marini, Maria Morganti, Giuliana Prucca, Benedikt Reichenbach, Guy Schraenen, Max Schumann, David Senior, Elisa Sighicelli, Ken Soehner, Francesco Spampinato, Elena Volpato.

The amount reached will help to cover the expenses related to the cultural program that will animate the three days of the fair (location rental, installation, transports, hospitality, communication, logistics...).

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
- Share this campaign with your friends: https://igg.me/at/FLATartbookfair
- Follow us on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter
- Sign up for email updates on www.flatartbookfair.com
story_txt: WHO WE AREFLAT is an idea by FLAT, the namesake no-profit cultural association that actively want to play a part in promoting and supporting the book and its distribution, by recognizing its important role in the diffusion and knowledge of contemporary art contents.FLAT was founded in Turin by Chiara Caroppo, Beatrice Merz and Mario Petriccione, professionals in the contemporary art field, with the aim of creating an important platform for promoting and selling artists’ books, as well as a hub for the production and exchange of ideas.We want to offer a space for promoting the finest international production of exhibition catalogs, monographs, essays, artists’ books, rare and out-of-print editions and magazines, while presenting a valuable show for leading publishers and small, independent presses, artists, collectors and bibliophiles from all over the world.Maria Morganti, Leporello 30 strati #5, Venezia, 2008 (ph. Francesco Allegretto)WHY WE NEED YOUR SUPPORTWe imagined to offer to the public an event that is accompanied by an extensive cultural program exploring the state of the international art publishing industry, alongside the practices and issues within the art-book culture.FLAT’s CULTURAL PROGRAM features two exhibitions: the monographic show on Ettore Sottsass. Le pagine and the group exhibit Lettura per voci e silenzio, both curated by Elena Volpato. The exhibition on Ettore Sottsass is hosted in the rooms of Palazzo Birago, institutional seat of the Chamber of Commerce of Torino, chosen to celebrate the centennial of Sottsass’s birth and the unlimited creativity of an artist who, more than others, truly expressed himself through books and magazines, each time reinventing the shape, the meaning, and the function of the printed page. The display will offer visitors a chance to see the entire production of Sottsass’s books, periodicals and pamphlets.The exhibit dedicated to Ettore Sottsass is complemented by the show Lettura per voci e silenzio, also curated by Elena Volpato and hosted at Palazzo Cisterna, venue of the Fair’s first edition. This exhibit is devoted to the liturgy of reading, intended both as an inner space and as a public space, an act of sharing. Some works, disseminated among the publishers’ desks in the Fair, allow visitors to listen to the voices of artists and performers reading various texts in front of the camera. They are the videos by John Baldessari, Three Feathers and Other Fairy Tales, by Martha Rosler, Martha Rosler Reads "Vogue", a work by Karl Holmqvist, I’m with you in Rockland and the choral work by Concetta Modica, In pasto al presente #3.In a separate, secluded area, is a series of small rooms hosting about thirty works, creating an island of quietness where the space of the page and the countless shapes of the books imagined by the artists will be allowed to disclose their silence. Visitors will plunge into the perceptive infinity of Romanzo blu by Irma Blank; they will stand in front of a small block of white chalk, silent and dense, on which Paolo Icaro has inscribed the word Racconto (Tale); they will consider the endless imaginary pages and volumes adding up on Giulio Paolini’s canvases; they will read the white transparency in between words where Sabrina Mezzaqui has rewritten Karen Blixen’s The Blank Page: and finally, in the volume Universum by Maurizio Nannucci, they will contemplate an elliptic closing within itself, with two opposite bindings wrapping a book into a closed volume, into a hermetic microcosmos—the image of a “book-world”, and of a world that throughout the ages cyclically appears to men as a silent book waiting to be read. The fair will be sided by FLAT Public Programs, a multifaceted series of lectures, talks, conversations, readings, screenings, music and book launches. On the occasion of FLAT international artists, designers, curators, professionals and experts from the art and artist publishing world gather in Turin to present and discuss the relevance of the book as an object, medium and instrument for art, its distribution and circulation. Here the list of participants: Francesco Arena, Luca Bertolo, Irma Boom, Collective Çukurcuma (Naz Cuguoglu and Mine Kaplangi), Nicoletta Boschiero, Liliana Dematteis, Heather Ewing, Eleonora Farina, Richard Flood, Wilfried Huet, Andrea Marini, Maria Morganti, Giuliana Prucca, Benedikt Reichenbach, Guy Schraenen, Max Schumann, David Senior, Elisa Sighicelli, Ken Soehner, Francesco Spampinato, Elena Volpato.The amount reached will help to cover the expenses related to the cultural program that will animate the three days of the fair (location rental, installation, transports, hospitality, communication, logistics...).OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP- Share this campaign with your friends: https://igg.me/at/FLATartbookfair- Follow us on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter- Sign up for email updates on www.flatartbookfair.com

story:
Hi there! I'm Nora, and this campaign would send me to Tokyo, Japan in October for ten days.

I've been before, and would love to return. I love the culture, every part of it. The cities, the towns, the food, the people. It all feels like home to me. I feel more myself than I ever have there, and I would love to go back with your help.

I have a magnitude of perks in mind for those generous and kind enough to help me achieve this!

I EVEN LEARNED HIRAGANA SO I CAN READ THE SIGNS OH DEAR GOD
私を助けてください?

I've set the goal for this campaign at $2,000. This goal will cover the costs of the flight, the hotel, and other expenses during the trip.

Such expenses include:

  • food and dining to sustain my ever growing form
  • a day trip to Mt. Fuji and hot springs at the base of the mountain (exclusive lewd photos of this are a perk)
  • a possible day trip to Kyoto, time and funds permitting
  • train fare - from and to the airport, and daily transportation
  • maid cafe with cute cute cute girls
  • sumo wrestling tournament or kabuki show
  • more cute girls
  • souvenirs - for myself and for you!

These are all fluid plans, depending on if we meet goal! If we don't reach our goal, the funds will still go towards the trip. Every cent helps, and I've been saving as much as I can myself. 

Many perks are available! :) Please don't hesitate to contact me here or via Twitter if you'd like a custom perk or would like to add to them.

I understand that some people can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help out in other ways. Even a dollar is lovely! 

What you can do:

  • Share this campaign as best as you can - on a blog post, a facebook post, a tweet, or a carrier pigeon. 
  • If you'd rather not donate via IGG, I'm open to other forms as well! Venmo, circlepay, square cash, giftrocket, airbnb giftcards, etc! Let me know what works best for you.

And that's that! Please help all you can, I am eternally grateful for everything!

♥ ♥ ♥ Nora

story:
Seachdain na Gàidhlig: 3-10 Samhain 2017

Edinburgh Gaelic Festival: 3-10 November 2017

Tha Seachdain na Gàidhlig air a ruith le comataidh saor-thoileach, le diofar buidhnean agus daoine a' gabhail pàirt ann. 

The Edinburgh Gaelic Festival is run by a committee of volunteers, with diverse organisations and people taking part.

Thòisich Seachdain na Gàidhlig aig Oilthigh Dhùn Èideann ann an 2014 le coig tachartasan. Ann an 2015, às dèidh dà fhèis shoirbheachail, chaidh aontachadh gum bu chòir dhan fhèis a bhuntainn ris a' bhaile air fad. 

The Edinburgh Gaelic Festival began at the University of Edinburgh in 2014 with only five events. In 2015, after two successful weeks, it was decided that the festival should belong to all of Edinburgh.

An uiridh, bha mu 30 tachartasan againn. Tha sinn air a bhith a' fàs gach bliadhna, agus tha sinn airson cumail oirnn! Tha tachartasan airson a h-uile duine san fhèis, bho dhaoine gun Ghàidhlig idir gu fileantaich.

Last year, we had around 30 events. We've been growing each year, and we'd like to keep on growing! Our festival offers something for everyone, from those who would like to know more about Gaelic to those who are fluent speakers.

Tha sinn glè thaingeil airson taic a fhuair sinn sam àm a dh'fhalbh bho Oilthigh Dhùn Èideann, Comann na Gàidhlig, agus Bòrd na Gàidhlig, agus a-nis tha sinn airson atharrachadh gu modail 'grassroots'.

We are very grateful for past funding we've had from the University of Edinburgh, Comann na Gàidhlig, and Bòrd na Gàidhlig, and we're now in a position to move toward a more 'grassroots' model.

Ma tha thu airson 's gum bi sinn a' togail aire mu àite na Gàidhlig ann an Dùn Èideann gu h-eachdraidheal agus san latha an-diugh, agus a' cruthachadh chothroman airson coimhearsnachd Gàidhlig sa bhaile a thighinn còmhla, tha sinn ag iarraidh gum bi thu mar phàirt dheth! 

If you'd like us to highlight Gaelic's historic and contemporary place in Edinburgh and to create opportunities for Edinburgh's Gaelic community to come together, we want you to be part of it!

Na dh'fheumas sinn & na gheibh thusa | What we need & what you get

  • Thèid an t-airgead air fad a dh'ionnsaigh dealbhachadh agus clo-bhualadh prògraman agus postairean, òstaireachd agus leasachadh ar làrach-lìn, foillseachadh na fèise, agus cosgaisean na tachartasan a ruitheas SnaG fhèin.
  • All money raised will go toward designing and printing festival programmes and posters, hosting and developing our website, publicising the festival, and running costs for the events hosted by the Edinburgh Gaelic Festival.
  • Tha sinn a' tabhann 'perks' tarraingeach dhan fheadhainn a chuireas taic chun na fèise. Tha lèintean-t agus geansaidhean SnaG rim faighinn airson do chumail fasanta agus do thaic a shealltainn, agus tha duaisean eile bho bhuidhnean agus daoine a tha a' cur taic rinn. 
  • We are offering some exciting perks for those who support the festival - a variety of Edinburgh Gaelic Festival merchandise to keep you looking sharp while showing your support as well as additional perks generously donated by groups and individuals supporting the festival. 
  • Mur an ruig sinn ar n-amas, bidh a h-uile sgillinn a fhuair sinn a' dol fhathast gu cosgaisean ruith na fèise, mar a mhìnich sinn gu h-uasal. Feuchaidh sinn ri taic-airgid fhaighinn ann an dòighean eile airson an fhèis a chumail a' dol.
  • If we do not make our target, all funds raise will still go to festival running costs as detailed above. We will seek other funding options to attempt to make up any shortfall.

Dòighean eile airson ar cuideachadh | Other ways to help

 

Tha fios againn nach eil e comasach dhan a h-uile duine tabhartas airgid a dhèanamh. Nam bu toil leibh ar cuideachadh ann an dòigh eile, bhitheamaid taingeil!

We know it isn't possible for everyone to donate. If you would like to help us in another way, we'd still be very grateful!

  • Sgaoil fios! Dèan 'share' air na meadhanan sòisealta, no bruidhinn ri daoine eile mun fhèis.
  • Spread the word! Share our information on social media, or speak to others about the festival.
  • Dèan ad! Tha sinn air pàtran-fighe a chruthachadh: ad le suaicheantas SnaG air. Leig fios ma tha thu ag iarraidh barrachd fiosrachaidh.
  • Make a hat! We've created a knitting pattern: a hat with our logo on it. Let us know if you'd like more info.
  • Cuir ris an fhèis! Ma tha thu airson tachartas a chur air dòigh, ar cuideachadh le obair san t-seachdain fhèin, no ann an dòigh sam bith eile, leig fios thugainn. 
  • Volunteer! If you'd like to organise an event, help us out by volunteering during the week itself, or if you have another way you'd like to contribute, let us know.
  • Thig ann! Thig dhan fhèis fhèin - bu toil leinn gu mòr d' fhaicinn ann.
  • Come along! Attend events during the festival itself - we'd love to see you there.

Mìle taing airson seo a leughadh! Tha sinn a' coimhead air adhart ri seo a chur an gnìomh còmhla riut.

Thanks very much for reading! We're looking forward to working together to make this happen.

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/edgaelfest/ 

Twitter: https://twitter.com/SnaGaidhlig 

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/seachdain.na.gaidhlig/ 

www.seachdainnagaidhlig.com | www.edinburghgaelicfestival.com

seachdain.na.gaidhlig@gmail.com

story:
My name is Sean Moore and I'm the founder of Swans Nest Yoga.  I was born with a good lottery ticket - great family, safe neighborhood, and access to a multitude of opportunities and life experiences.  I've worked on Wall Street, DJ'ed in New York City, and travelled the world while working for Acumen - an international organization bringing innovative and affordable goods and services to the poor.  My life has been blessed in many ways.  But like many of us, I've struggled with anxiety, depression and finding fulfillment. 

There's a teaching from the Rigveda - an ancient Indian philosophical text - that states "Truth is One, Paths Are Many."  Yoga has been my path towards Truth, or a feeling of wholeness within myself.  I began teaching yoga in studios and out of my apartment in New York City in 2016 and spent two months studying at the KPJAYI institute in Mysore, India in early 2018.  It was there that I committed to launching my own yoga school, and on August 18, 2018, I opened the doors to Swans Nest Yoga.

After a great first 7 months laying down roots, building community, and spending way too much time trying to insulate a drafty window with plastic sheets and a hair dryer (3rd time's the charm!), I now have the exciting opportunity to expand the yoga room and create a vibrant entrance room for workshops, creative events, and general hang time! 

I'm raising $15,555 to finance this expansion and implement the first installation of "Burning To Live":  A 12 week workshop intended to help us connect with our authentic selves and reach our full potential through regular yoga practice, exploration of Eastern and Western philosophies, creative projects, and exposure to spiritual and wisdom teachings such as the Enneagram, Numerology, Astrology and Tarot.  

As a new yoga school in New York City we are still building our student base and will need to continue to grow to become financially sustainable.  With your support, as well as the commitment of our current investors, I believe we will be able to build an exciting and influential organization that can sustain itself in the long-term and be of service to anyone seeking out the teachings of yoga.  

Yoga has been the most impactful tool I've found to reduce stress, anxiety and depression in my life and increase joy and purpose within myself.  By supporting this campaign you will enable us to create a truly special yoga shala for students to practice in, learn about themselves, express their creativity, and reach their highest potential.  I would be so grateful for any level of donation you can provide and am extremely excited to continue to build this community with your support!

Check out our Perks for what you get in return for your financial support!

If you can't support financially but would like to help, please use the Indiegogo share tools and any other means to share this campaign with whomever you think would be interested in supporting!

Thank You!

Sean Moore aka Swan
Founder, Swans Nest Yoga
(also professional email writer; amateur freestyle rapper; in between professional/amateur DJ)

story:
Gali Durugappa hails from a village next to Hampi, a historical town in Karnataka, India. He started to learn music by himself and from brief lessons by travellers less than ten years ago, and can now play over a dozen instruments with ease. Be it hang-drums, didgeridoos, flutes, guitars, djembes, or ukuleles, Gali knows how each works! He is set up a small shop in Hampi where he sells musical instruments and encourages visitors to go out of their comfort zone to try out the instruments. Everyone is welcome in this humble abode!


Gali says, "My dream is to build a community centre where music can bring individuals together, a place of happiness, comfort and friendship. That is my only dream"!


Gali has already brought so many together, as easy as pie. He conducts sound healing meditation early in the mornings for anyone who would like to participate. At the end of these sessions, every person leaves with content evident on their face!


However, his tiny shop is set to be shut down by the authorities very soon. And now he needs your help, his friends, fans, visitors, and strangers (who will soon be friends!) to build the community that will be the place you can retreat to.


"Any amount big or small will help me immensely", says Gali, as he tries to keep the spirit of Hampi alive through music every day.

However, his tiny shop is set to be shut down by the authorities very soon. And now he needs your help, his friends, fans, visitors, and strangers (who will soon be friends!) to build the community that will be the place you can retreat to.
"Any amount big or small will help me immensely", says Gali, as he tries to keep the spirit of Hampi alive through music every day.

story:
Hi Folks, 

Thank you so much for taking the time to read this. My brothers and I opened the doors of Nine Dot Gallery in Worcester, MA in 2015. Our mission was to create a space that would be a real resource in supporting our creative community. Fast-forward to over 50 events, 24 exhibitions, and one relocation later we now share space with the Southeast Asian Coalition of Central Massachusetts. This move ushered a more social justice focus in collaboration with our refugee and immigrant artist and maker community. 

On The Go

To facilitate more cultural exchange, we have decided to pay it forward. On May 22nd, we will be in Vietnam setting up an art exchange that we hope to transform into a residency. Nine Dot Gallery is the little engine that could, and with your help we can. We have our tickets and enough capital to do a bare bones trip. But we want to leave a larger impact. With your contributions we will be able to host workshops in Hanoi, Saigon, and Can Tho. These workshops will be on the topics of material studies, creative placemaking, and cultural equity.  

Back home

Through out our exchanges in Vietnam we will be putting together an artist roster for our returning exhibition in Worcester, Ma. The show will feature works paired from our local community highlighting the cultural connection made in our travels.  We'll also have the pleasure to introduce Worcester Art Museum's first artist in resident.  

Comes with fries

Along with our creative mission, this year we will be helping Youth Effect International with their humanitarian efforts in 2 remote locations: Hop Tien Village, a refuge for victims of human trafficking, and Chua Buu Tri orphanage, a safe space that supports homeless children from ages 2-18. We'll be delivering basic everyday goods that any human would need. These goods are things such as hygiene products, clothing, and school supplies.  

Together 

Setting up the platform for this cultural exchange will be demanding with our skeleton crew. The programming, implementing and documentation are all full-time affairs, respectively. But with your help we'll be able to maximize our impact, support local artists, and grow our creative community. Without your funding we won't be able to reach all of the planned sites to create points of collaboration. Flexibility is everything and if we can't reach our goal we'll have to scale down our footprint. It's with your support we will be able to create cultural and artistic exchange between countries.   

Help us connect the dots

Please consider funding our project. We know everyone can't contribute financially. But collectively we can share and spread the word. Thanks so much for your efforts and making art connective!

story:
About Us - The Event Coordinators

We are an event coordination team of two postgraduate students from the Middlesex University, London. The live music event is operated on behalf of the music festival brand 'Hanwell Hootie'.

Benjamin Albrecht, with a background in music production and project management, contributes the needed knowledge of live music events and industry insights to this project. His colleague, Shihan Jia, completes the team with in-depth experience in marketing and economics. This combination of skills represents the perfect requirements for setting up such event.

As Arts Management students and musicians, we are pleased to offer upcoming and independent artists a platform to present their skills and promote their music to a potential fan base. Additionally, the event is a fantastic chance to meet industry professionals and receive valuable feedback. Knowing the struggles of new bands, we deeply understand the need for the possibility to catch the attention of industry representatives.

The Inter-University Band Contest 

The event will take place on 16th March 2018 at a London's premier live music venue. It is a contest between six bands sent by music colleges and university music faculties, along with industry professionals acting as judges. We aim to support the uprising bands with a real networking opportunity within the industry and expand their audience base. 

During the three hours of live music, the guests will have the chance to explore, enjoy a broad range of music and celebrate the weekend. The main prize of the band competition will give the winner the opportunity to perform on stage at the Hanwell Hootie 2018 festival. The performance of each participant will be rated by following industry professionals:

  • Andy McRobbie - Music Director of Hanwell Hootie
  • George Corton - A&R Manager of Tileyard Music
  • Joseph Lever - Event Coordinator of Music Managers Forum
  • Steve Tannett - Managing Director of Marshall Records

The participating bands are:

  1. Tokyo and Roses - King's College London
  2. The Sages - SOAS University of London
  3. Sam Gifford and the Innocent - Middlesex University London
  4. Mardhys - Academy of Contemporary Music
  5. Sans Soucis Experience - London College of Creative Media
  6. Beezley - British and Irish Modern Music Institute

As university students, we started the project from zero budget in December 2017. We appreciate the participation of Hanwell Hootie, which provided excellent support and confidence for us, without which, we wouldn't make it.

The pie chart above is the cost breakdown of the event. To be able to realise a music event with around 40 musicians, it is necessary to hire the appropriate event staff. The production team not only consists of event technicians and stagehands but also front of the house and security staff. Thus, we plan to fundraise via Indiegogo to compensate our human resources costs. We sincerely ask you to help financially to push the project a step forward.

What You Give Us & What You Get

We provide you with a wide range of perks; some of them offer a unique experience. Take your time and read through the perk list on the right-hand side. The Perks are starting from £5 and go up to £150; some of them have a limited amount. If you have any questions, feel free to contact us or leave a comment on this Indiegogo page.

Other Ways You Can Help Us

If you just don't have the necessary money right now, this is fine. Instead of your financial support, you can help us by sharing this crowdfunding campaign with your friends and family to increase our chance to find particular backers. Use the by Indiegogo provided tools to spread our band contest concept. Thank you very much for your support!

story:
Hi, my name is Rajah Caruth. I am a student-athlete and a rising junior at School Without Walls Senior High School in Washington D.C. I run track and play basketball for my school, however my true love is NASCAR and I have always wanted to be a racecar driver. Ever since age 6, I have loved the sport and know everything in and around it. The Pixar movie ‘Cars’ is what got me into the sport, and as the years have gone by, my love and knowledge for NASCAR has grown exponentially. The cars truly mesmerized me, with their sleek bodies and flashy paint schemes. I collected tons of model cars and made custom ones along with homemade tracks.

 

I created a Youtube channel in the summer of 2014 that included stop motion animation videos, music videos, race reactions and reviews. Later that year, I went to my first race, the fall Xfinity Series race at Richmond Raceway on a Friday evening in September. This was especially impactful because I loved this sport for so long, and never had the opportunity to go to a race, since the nearest racetrack was at least an hour’s travel in any direction. It was truly a spectacle; and it just fueled the flame of my dream of making it to the other side of the fence.

 

Following that, I was able to go to multiple Xfinity races at Dover and Pocono, two Truck races (Dover ‘17, Charlotte ‘18), along with the Monster Energy NASCAR 2018 All Star Race. As I got older, I began to realize that the opportunities that are present for me to drive are limited, and that I had to get creative if I wanted to be apart of NASCAR. I took the first steps in 2017 by joining the Autobahn Indoor Speedway summer league in Jessup, MD. I drove very competitively and improved each race I was in.  

 

On June 11th this year, I turned 16 and my desire to have a career in NASCAR has grown even more, especially after attending the 2018 All-Star Race in Charlotte.

 

This summer, I plan to take another step forward in my career by joining the Ignite Series, a NASCAR eleague run on the iRacing simulation program, an online platform which allows me to compete with professional racers around the world and provides a way to be in NASCAR. Participating in this program will allow me to develop my skills, network and provide a possible pathway to become a successful driver similar to those like William Byron, Ty Majeski and other pros who made it to NASCAR through the program.

 

I am asking for your help and support as I try to raise $2000 in order to pay for my iRacing membership, a driving wheel and a basic computer to run the racing program and participate in the 2018 Autobahn Indoor Speedway summer league.

 

Thank you for your support.
